ferc_filing_data.tariff_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff, Third Revised Volume No. 5

record_data.record_narrative_name: Long-Term Firm and Short-Term Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service
record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 7 Long-Term Firm and Short-Term Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service I. The Transmission Customer shall compensate the Transmission Provider each month for Reserved Capacity at the sum of the applicable charges set forth below: 1) Yearly delivery: one-twelfth of the demand charge of $17.8800/KW of Reserved Capacity per year. 2) Monthly delivery: $1.4900/KW of Reserved Capacity per month. 3) Weekly delivery: $0.3440/KW of Reserved Capacity per week. 4)Daily delivery: $0.0570/KW of Reserved Capacity per day. 5)Discounts: Three principal requirements apply to discounts for transmission service as follows (1) any offer of a discount made by the Transmission Provider must be announced to all Eligible Customers solely by posting on the OASIS, (2) any customer-initiated requests for discounts (including requests for use by one s wholesale merchant or an affiliate s use) must occur solely by posting on the OASIS, and (3) once a discount is negotiated, details must be immediately posted on the OASIS. For any discount agreed upon for service on a path from point(s) of receipt to point(s) of delivery, the Transmission Provider must offer the same discounted transmission service rate for the same time period to all Eligible Customers on all unconstrained transmission paths that go to the same point(s) of delivery on the Transmission System.
record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 8 Non-Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service I. The Transmission Customer shall compensate the Transmission Provider monthly for Non-Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service up to the sum of the applicable charges set forth below: 1) Monthly delivery: $1.4900/KW of Reserved Capacity per month. 2) Weekly delivery: $0.3440/KW of Reserved Capacity per week. 3) Daily delivery: $0.0570/KW of Reserved Capacity per day. 4)Hourly delivery: The basic charge shall be that agreed upon by the Parties at the time this service is reserved and in no event shall exceed $3.82/MWH. 5)Discounts: Three principal requirements apply to discounts for transmission service as follows (1) any offer of a discount made by the Transmission Provider must be announced to all Eligible Customers solely by posting on the OASIS, (2) any customer-initiated requests for discounts (including requests for use by one s wholesale merchant or an affiliate s use) must occur solely by posing on the OASIS, and (3) once a discount is negotiated, details must be immediately posted on the OASIS. For any discount agreed upon for service on a path, from point(s) of receipt to point(s) of delivery, the Transmission Provider must offer the same discounted transmission service rate for the same time period to all Eligible Customers on all unconstrained transmission paths that go to the same point(s) of delivery on the Transmission System. 6) Offer of Next Hour Market Service: The Transmission Provider is adopting the North American Electric Reliability Council s Next Hour Market Service, as accepted by the Commission in its Order of December 16, 1999, at Docket No. ER00-157-000 (89 FERC 61,277 (1999)).
record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 5 Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service Spinning Reserve Service is needed to serve load immediately in the event of a system contingency. Spinning Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Spinning Reserve Service obligation. The amount of and charges for Spinning Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the Transmission Customer are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Spinning Reserve Service shall be determined by multiplying the Customer's Reserved Capacity/Spinning Capacity for Point-to-Point Customers, or Network Load/Spinning Capacity for Network Transmission Service, by the following applicable rates: (a) The amount of Spinning Capacity is equal to 1.50 percent (to be adjusted from time to time to reflect the then current spinning reserve requirement for the Transmission Provider as determined by its regional reliability council) times the Reserved Capacity/Network Load or Monthly Network Load, as appropriate for the billing period. (b) The charges for this service when supplied by the Transmission Provider will be based on the following rates:* (i) Yearly delivery: $1.38600/KW per year of Reserved Capacity/Network Load, or $92.40000/KW of Spinning Capacity per year. (ii) Monthly delivery: $0.11550/KW per month of Reserved Capacity/Monthly Network Load, or $7.70000/KW of Spinning Capacity per month. (iii) Weekly delivery: $0.02665/KW per week of Reserved Capacity per week, or $1.77690/KW of Spinning Capacity per week. (iv) Daily delivery: $0.00444/KW per day of Reserved Capacity, or $0.29615/KW of Spinning Capacity per day. (v) Hourly delivery: $0.00029/KW per hour of Reserved Capacity/Network Load, or $0.01974/KW of Spinning Capacity per hour. Charges for Spinning Reserve Service will be: (a) equal to the charges listed in (i) or (ii) above for Network Integrated Transmission Service, or (b) equal to (i) through (iv) above for Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service, or (c) up to (ii) through (v) above for Non-Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service. *Rates are listed in two formats. First, the amount of service required and the charge for the service are listed separately to allow customers to compare the cost of service with that offered by other providers. For the convenience of the customer, if Allegheny Power provides the service, the second rate calculates the actual rate using the figures provided in the first format. The second format is the same as the rate presentation for basic transmission services (i.e., $KW for Yearly, Monthly, Daily, and Hourly service).
record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 6 Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service Supplemental Reserve Service is needed to serve load in the event of a system contingency; however, it is not available immediately to serve load but rather within a short period of time. Supplemental Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line but unloaded, by quick-start generation or by interruptible load. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The Transmission Customer must either purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or make alternative comparable arrangements to satisfy its Supplemental Reserve Service obligation. The amount of and charges for Supplemental Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the Transmission Customer are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service shall be determined by multiplying the Customer's Supplemental Capacity for Point-to-Point Transmission Service, or Network Load for Network Integration Transmission Service, by the following applicable rates: (a) The amount of Supplemental Capacity is equal to 1.50 percent (to be adjusted from time to time to reflect the then current supplemental reserve requirement for the Transmission Provider as determined by its regional reliability council) times the Reserved Capacity/Network Load or Monthly Network Load, as appropriate for the billing period. (b) The charges for this service when supplied by the Transmission Provider will be based on the following rates*: (i) Yearly delivery: $1.38600/KW of Reserved Capacity/Network Load, or $92.40000/KW of the Supplemental Capacity per year. (ii) Monthly delivery: $0.11550/KW of Reserved Capacity/Monthly Network Load per month, or $7.70000/KW of Supplemental Capacity per month. (iii) Weekly delivery: $0.02665/KW of Reserved Capacity per week, or $1.77690/KW of Supplemental Capacity per week. (iv) Daily delivery: $0.00444/KW of Reserved Capacity per day, or $0.29615/KW of Supplemental Capacity per day. (v) Hourly delivery: $0.00029/KW of Reserved Capacity per hour, or $0.01974/KW of Supplemental Capacity per hour. Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service will be: (a) equal to (i) or (ii) above for Network Integrated Transmission Service, or (b) equal to (i) through (iv) above for Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service, or (c) up to (ii) through (v) above for Non-Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service. *Rates are listed in two formats. First, the amount of service required and the charge for the service are listed separately to allow customers to compare the cost of service with that offered by other providers. For the convenience of the customer, if Allegheny Power provides the service, the second rate calculates the actual rate using the figures provided in the first format. The second format is the same as the rate presentation for basic transmission services (i.e., $KW for Yearly, Monthly, Daily, and Hourly service).
record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 11 TABLE OF CONTENTS I. Definitions----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1 Electricity Supplier (ES)------------------------------------------------ 2 Designated Agent--------------------------------------------------------- 3 Marginal Hourly Price-------------------------------------------------- II. Terms and Conditions-------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers------ 7.1 Billing Procedure-------------------------------------------------------- 7.3 Customer Default-------------------------------------------------------- Section 11 Creditworthiness--------------------------------------------------------------- Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service------------------------------ Section 28.4 Secondary Service----------------------------------------------------------- Section 28.5 Real Power Losses------------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service-------------------------------- Section 29.2 Application Procedures-------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities-------------------------------------------------- Section 34 Rates and Charges-------------------------------------------------------------- i Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service------------------------------------------------------------------------- ii Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service--------------------- iii Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources----- Service------------------------------------------------------------------------- iv Regulation and Frequency Response Service---------------------------- v Charges for Energy Imbalance Service----------------------------------- Supply Energy Imbalance--------------------------------------------------- Consumption Energy Imbalance------------------------------------------- vi Charges for Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service--------- vii Charges for Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service---- Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee--------------------------------------------- Schedule 1 Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service----------------------- Schedule 2 Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service--------------------------------------------------------------------------- Schedule 3 Regulation and Frequency Response Service----------------------------- Schedule 4 Energy Imbalance Service---------------------------------------------------- Supply Energy Imbalance---------------------------------------------------- Consumption Energy Imbalance--------------------------------------------- Schedule 5 Operating Reserve Spinning Reserve Service-------------------------- Schedule 6 Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service--------------------- Schedule 9 Real Power Transmission Loss Service------------------------------------ Network Operating Agreement-------------------------------------------------------------- Section 4.4 Scheduling of Network Integration Transmission Service------------ Section 5.0 Default------------------------------------------------------------------------- Attachment H Annual Transmission Revenue Requirement for Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service--------------------------------------------------------------------- RETAIL TRANSMISSION SERVICE - MARYLAND Retail transmission services pursuant to the Commission s Order Nos. 888, 888-A and B, 889 and 889-A and B shall be made available under this Schedule 11 to unbundled retail customers in the state of Maryland with the right to choose their electric suppliers. Service shall be provided according to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Tariff which is hereby incorporated herein except as modified below. I.Definitions 1.Electricity Supplier (ES) shall mean a person or corporation, (including municipal corporations which choose to provide service outside their municipal limits as prescribed by state law), broker or marketer, aggregator, scheduling coordinator, or any other entity selling to end-use customers (including an electric distribution company providing service as a provider of last resort) electricity or related services utilizing the jurisdictional transmission and distribution facilities of an electric distribution company. 2.Designated Agent shall mean any entity that performs actions or functions on behalf of the Transmission Provider, an Eligible Customer, or the Transmission Customer required under the Tariff. 3.Marginal Hourly Price shall mean the price at which Consumption Energy Imbalance will be traded. The price is the Transmission Provider s out-of-pocket cost for energy purchased during the hour in which the Consumption Energy Imbalance occurs. Terms and Conditions Retail Transmission Services shall be provided pursuant to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Service Tariff, as amended ( OATT ) except as modified below. The ES(s) shall act as a Designated Agent for an Eligible Customer(s), unless otherwise indicated below. Section 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers. Eligible Customers classified as retail customers taking unbundled transmission service pursuant to a state requirement that the Transmission Provider offer the transmission service, or pursuant to a voluntary offer of such service by the Transmission Provider with a contract term of one-year or more have the right to continue to take transmission service from the Transmission Provider when the contract expires, rolls over or is renewed. This transmission reservation priority is independent of whether the existing customer continues to purchase capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider or elects to purchase capacity and energy from another ES. If at the end of the contract term the Transmission Provider s Transmission System cannot accommodate all of the requests for transmission service, the existing firm service customer must agree to accept a contract term at least equal to a competing request by any new Eligible Customer and to pay the current just and reasonable rate, as approved by the Commission, for such service. This transmission reservation priority for existing retail firm service customers is an ongoing right that may be exercised at the end of all firm contract terms of one-year or longer. Section 7.1 Billing Procedure Within a reasonable time after the first day of each month, the Transmission Provider shall submit an invoice to the ES for charges for all Network Integrated Transmission Service and Ancillary Services furnished under the Tariff during the preceding month. Charges for Network Integrated Transmission Service, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control, Regulation and Frequency Response, Operative Reserve Spinning and Operating Reserve Supplemental services shall be based on meter data collected from Eligible Customer(s) within the calendar month. The Transmission Provider shall also charge the ES for any Supply Energy Imbalance service rendered to the ES during the calendar month and for an estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance as related to the calendar month. Approximately 60 days later, the ES shall also be billed an adjustment for Consumption Energy Imbalance after all Eligible Customer(s) energy usage occurring during the calendar month is collected from meter readings and processed. This adjustment will be determined as the difference between such estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance and the Consumption Energy Imbalance determined after meter data collection. The invoices shall be paid by the ES within twenty (20) days of receipt. All payments shall be made in immediately available funds payable to the Transmission Provider, or by wire transfer to a bank named by the Transmission Provider. Section 7.3 Customer Default In the event the ES fails for any reason other than a billing dispute as described below, to make payment to the Transmission Provider on or before the due date as described above, and such failure of payment is not corrected within thirty (30) calendar days after the Transmission Provider notifies the ES to cure such failure, a default by the ES shall be deemed to exist. Upon the occurrence of a default, the Transmission Provider may initiate a proceeding with the Commission to terminate service but shall not terminate service until the Commission so approves any such request; provided however, that in the event that a state required retail access program provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another ES, then the Transmission Provider may, upon default by an ES, immediately terminate service to the defaulting ES for the load of such end-use customers. In the event of a billing dispute between the Transmission Provider and the ES, the Transmission Provider will continue to provide service under the Service Agreement as long as the ES (i) continues to make all payments not in dispute, and (ii) pays into an independent escrow account the portion of the invoice in dispute, pending resolution of such dispute. If the ES fails to meet these two requirements for continuation of service, then the Transmission Provider may provide notice to the ES of its intention to suspend service in sixty (60) days, in accordance with Commission policy, or in the case of a state required retail access program that provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another ES, immediately terminate transmission service to the defaulting ES as provided above. Section 11 Creditworthiness For the purpose of determining the ability of the Transmission Customer or ES to meet its obligations related to service hereunder, the Transmission Provider may require reasonable credit review procedures. The Transmission Customer or ES will be considered creditworthy if (1) the Transmission Customer s or ES s long-term unsecured debt securities are, and remain, rated a minimum of BBB or Baa2 by Standard & Poor s or Moody s, respectively, (b) the Transmission Customer or ES either prepays for service or provides an irrevocable standby letter of credit issued by a domestic or Canadian bank with a minimum A (Standard & Poor s or Dominion) or A2 (Moody s) long-term unsecured debt rating, for an amount equal to the sum of the charges pursuant to this Tariff for the shorter of (i) the three (3) individual months when such charges would be greatest, or (ii) the term of the Service Agreement based on mutually agreeable load factors pursuant to this Tariff, (c) the Transmission Customer or ES has, as determined by Allegheny Power in its sole discretion, a qualified long-term payment history with Allegheny Power, or (d) the Transmission Customer s or ES s parent company, in a form satisfactory to Allegheny Power, guarantees responsibility for all financial obligations associated with the Service Agreement and such parent company conforms to the minimum ratings specified above. Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service The Transmission Provider will provide firm transmission service over its Transmission System to the ES on behalf of its Eligible Customers for the delivery of capacity and energy from its designated Network Resources to service its Network Loads on a basis that is comparable to the Transmission Provider s use of the Transmission System to reliably serve its Native Load Customers. The ES must designate its Network Resources via NERC Tag by 1:00 p.m., one (1) business day before the delivery of power. Firm Available Transmission Capability will be awarded on a first-come, first-serve basis based on the receipt time of the NERC Tag. Section 28.4 Secondary Service The ES on behalf of its Eligible Customers may use the Transmission Provider s Transmission System to deliver energy to its Network Loads from resources that have not been designated as Network Resources. The ES shall request to change generation sources to non-Network Resources via NERC Tag. Such energy shall be transmitted, on an as-available-basis, at no additional charge. Deliveries from resources other than Network Resources will have a higher priority than any Non-Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service under Part II of the Tariff. Section 28.5 Real Power Losses Real Power Losses are associated with all transmission service. The ES is responsible for supplying losses associated with its Eligible Customer(s). The applicable Real Power Loss factors are as listed below in Schedule 9 of this Schedule 11. Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service Subject to the terms and conditions of Part III of the Tariff, the Transmission Provider will provide Network Integration Transmission Service to any Eligible Customer, provided that (i) the Eligible Customer completes an Application for service as provided under Part III of the Tariff, as required (ii) the Eligible Customer and the Transmission Provider complete the technical arrangements set forth in Sections 29.3 and 29.4, (iii) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Service Agreement with the Commission, and (iv) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Network Operating Agreement with the Commission pursuant to Attachment G. The Eligible Customer and ES shall be bound by the Terms and Conditions of the OATT including this Schedule 11. Section 29.2 Application Procedures An Eligible Customer (or a Designated Agent) requesting service under Part III of the Tariff may be required to submit an Application, with a deposit approximating the charge for one month of service, to the Transmission Provider as far as possible in advance of the month in which service is to commence. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Transmission Provider may, on a non-discriminatory basis, waive the requirement that a deposit accompany an Application where the Eligible Customer has established its creditworthiness pursuant to Section 11 of this Tariff and is not in default in its obligation under this Section 7.3 of this Tariff at the time of Application. The Transmission Provider will bill the Eligible Customer for any reasonable costs incurred by the Transmission Provider in connection with its review of the Application. Such bill will contain a complete accounting of all costs included. Unless subject to the procedures in Section 2, Completed Applications for Network Integration Transmission Service will be assigned a priority according to the date and time the Application is received, with the earliest Application receiving the highest priority. Applications should be submitted by entering the information listed below on the Transmission Provider s OASIS. Prior to implementation of the Transmission Provider s OASIS, a Completed Application may be submitted by (i) transmitting the required information to the Transmission Provider by telefax, or (ii) providing the information by telephone over the Transmission Provider s time recorded telephone line. Each of these methods will provide a time-stamped record for establishing the service priority of the Application. A Completed Application shall provide all of the information included in 18 CFR 2.20 including but not limited to the following: (i)The identity, address, telephone number and facsimile number of the party requesting service; (ii) A statement that the party requesting service is, or will be upon commencement of service, an Eligible Customer under the Tariff; (i)A description of the Network Load at each delivery point. This description should separately identify and provide the Eligible Customer s best estimate of the total loads to be served at each transmission voltage level, and the load to be served from each Transmission Provider substation at the same transmission voltage level. The description should include a ten (10) year forecast of summer and winter load and resource requirements beginning with the first year after the service is scheduled to commence; (ii)The amount and location of any interruptible loads included in the Network Load. This shall include the summer and winter capacity requirements for each interruptible load (had such load not been interruptible), that portion of the load subject to interruption, the conditions under which an interruption can be implemented and any limitations on the amount and frequency of interruptions. An Eligible Customer should identify the amount of interruptible customer load (if any) included in the 10 year load forecast provided in response to (iii) above; (iii)A description of Network Resources (current and 10-year projection), which shall include, for each Network Resource: Unit size and amount of capacity from that unit to be designated as Network Resource VAR capability (both leading and lagging) of all generators Operating restrictions Any periods of restricted operations throughout the year Maintenance schedules Minimum loading level of unit Normal operating level of unit Any must-run unit designations required for system reliability or contract reasons Approximate variable generating cost ($MWH) for redispatch computations Arrangement governing sale and delivery of power to third parties from generating facilities located in the Transmission Provider Control Area, where only a portion of unit output is designated as a Network Resource Description of purchased power designated as a Network Resource including source of supply, Control Area location, transmission arrangements and delivery point(s) to the Transmission Provider s Transmission System; (iv)Description of Eligible Customer s transmission system: Load flow and stability data, such as real and reactive parts of the load, lines, transformers, reactive devices and load type, including normal and emergency ratings of all transmission equipment in a load flow format compatible with that used by the Transmission Provider Operating restrictions needed for reliability Operating guides employed by system operators Contractual restrictions or committed uses of the Eligible Customers transmission system, other than the Eligible Customer s Network Loads and Resources Location of Network Resources described in subsection (v) above 10 year projection of system expansions or upgrades Transmission System maps that include any proposed expansions or upgrades Thermal ratings of Eligible Customer s Control Area ties with other Control Areas; and (v)Service Commencement Date and the term of the requested Network Integration Transmission Service. The minimum term for Network Integration Transmission Service is one year. Unless the Parties agree to a different time frame, the Transmission Provider must acknowledge the request within ten (10) days of receipt. The acknowledgement must include a date by which a response, including a Service Agreement, will be sent to the Eligible Customer. If an Application fails to meet the requirements of this section, the Transmission Provider shall notify the Eligible Customer requesting service within fifteen (15) days of receipt and specify the reasons for such failure. Wherever possible, the Transmission Provider will attempt to remedy deficiencies in the Application through informal communications with the Eligible Customer. If such efforts are unsuccessful, the Transmission Provider shall return the Application without prejudice to the Eligible Customer filing a new or revised Application that fully complies with the requirements of this section. The Eligible Customer will be assigned a new priority consistent with the date of the new or revised Application. The Transmission Provider shall treat this information consistent with the standards of conduct contained in Part 37 of the Commission's regulations. Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities The provision of Network Integration Transmission Service shall be conditioned upon the Eligible Customer's constructing, maintaining and operating the facilities on its side of each delivery point or interconnection necessary to reliably deliver capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider's transmission system to the Eligible Customer or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. The Eligible Customer shall be solely responsible for constructing or installing all facilities on the Eligible Customer's side of each such delivery point or interconnection or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. Section 34 Rates and Charges Charges shall be in accordance with OATT rates and charges except as listed below. The ES is responsible for paying all OATT charges on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). (i)Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service Charges for Network Integration Transmission Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) Retail Transmission Service charge. Network Integration Transmission Service charges are as listed in Attachment H of this Schedule 11. (ii)Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service There is no charge for this service. (iii) Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service Charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service. Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service charges are as listed in Schedule 2 of this Schedule 11. (iv) Regulation and Frequency Response Service Charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service. Regulation and Frequency Response Service charges are as listed in Schedule 3 of this Schedule 11. (v)Charges for Energy Imbalance Service Supply Energy Imbalance Charges for Supply Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between a Pre-schedule and associated Schedule(s). Supply Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 11. Consumption Energy Imbalance Charges for Consumption Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between the Pre-Schedule and the ES s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption. Consumption Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 11. (vi) Charges for Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service Charges for Spinning Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service. Operating Reserve Spinning Reserve Service charges are as listed in Schedule 5 of this Schedule 11. (vii) Charges for Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service. Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service charges are as listed in Schedule 6 of this Schedule 11. Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee A Network Operating Committee (Committee) may be established to coordinate operating criteria for the Parties' respective responsibilities for Eligible Customer(s) under the Network Operating Agreement. Each ES serving Eligible Customer(s) within the Transmission Provider's Control Area shall be entitled to have at least one representative on the Committee. The Committee shall meet from time to time as need requires. Schedule 1, Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service1 This service is required to schedule the movement of power through, out of, within, or into a Control Area. This service can be provided only by the operator of the Control Area in which the transmission facilities used for transmission service are located. Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator) or indirectly by the Transmission Provider making arrangements with the Control Area operator that performs this service for the Transmission Provider's Transmission System. The ES must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or the Control Area operator. The charges for Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service are to be based on the rates set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. There is no charge for this service. Schedule 2, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service2 In order to maintain transmission voltages on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities within acceptable limits, generation facilities under the control of the Control Area operator are operated to produce (or absorb) reactive power. Thus, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service must be provided for each transaction on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities. The amount of Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service that must be supplied with respect to the ES's transaction will be determined based on the reactive power support necessary to maintain transmission voltages within limits that are generally accepted in the region and consistently adhered to by the Transmission Provider. Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator) or indirectly by the Transmission Provider making arrangements with the Control Area operator that performs this service for the Transmission Provider's Transmission System. The ES must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s) from the Transmission Provider or the Control Area operator. The charges for such service will be based on the rates set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by the Control Area operator. Charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $.00021/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $.00024/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $.00024/kWh Rate Schedule C-A (commercial/industrial): $.00025/kWh Rate Schedule CSH (commercial): $.00025/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $.08/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $.072/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL, SL, EMU and MU (street and area lighting): $.00021/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $.027/kW Hagerstown & Frederick: $.00021/kWh Eastalco: $.25/kW Schedule 3, Regulation and Frequency Response Service3 Regulation and Frequency Response Service is necessary to provide for the continuous balancing of resources (generation and interchange) with load and for maintaining scheduled Interconnection frequency at sixty cycles per second (60 Hz). Regulation and Frequency Response Service is accomplished by committing on-line generation whose output is raised or lowered (predominantly through the use of automatic generating control equipment) as necessary to follow the moment-by-moment changes in load. The obligation to maintain this balance between resources and load lies with the Transmission Provider (or the Control Area operator that performs this function for the Transmission Provider). The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The ES must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $.00022/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $.00026/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $.00026/kWh Rate Schedule C-A (commercial/industrial): $.00027/kWh Rate Schedule CSH (commercial): $.00027/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $.08/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $.077/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL, SL, EMU and MU (street and area lighting): $.00026/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $.029/kW Hagerstown & Frederick: $.00026/kWh Eastalco: $.26/kW Schedule 4, Energy Imbalance Service4 Energy Imbalance Service is provided when a difference occurs between the scheduled and the actual delivery of energy to a load located within a Control Area over a single hour. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The ES must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Energy Imbalance Service will be provided if: 1.An imbalance exists between a Pre-Schedule(s) and associated Schedule(s), i.e., Supply Energy Imbalance. 2. An imbalance exists between a Pre-Schedule(s) and the actual metered consumption, i.e., Consumption Energy Imbalance. Supply Energy Imbalance Supply Energy Imbalance arises when there is the difference between a Pre-Schedule and associated Schedule(s). A Pre-Schedule is defined as an aggregate hourly projection of load or capacity, compiled by the Transmission Provider in a manner that is consistent with Control Area protocols, used to forecast generation and transmission transfer capability required to meet load for customers within the Transmission Provider's Control Area. One aggregate Pre-Schedule is compiled for each ES one business day before the delivery of power. A Schedule, based upon a Pre-Schedule, is prepared by an ES for receipt and delivery of capacity and energy for the benefit of customers; the ES submits the schedule to the Transmission Provider's Control Area in the format prescribed by the Transmission Provider. The Schedule or combination of Schedules is intended to meet the ES's Pre-Schedule. Discrepancies between a Pre-Schedule and associated Schedule(s) will occur if ES fails to meet its Pre-Schedule, in whole or in part. ES remains solely responsible for supplying a Schedule(s) and for notifying the Transmission Provider if it will not deliver power to meet its Pre- Schedule. ES' failure to supply a Schedule(s) or to deliver power to meet the Pre-Schedule will require the Transmission Provider's Control Area operator to automatically supply the deficient amount of power. Charges for Supply Energy Imbalance shall be equal to the greater of: (i) $0.10/KWh of such energy supply, or (ii) 110% of the out-of-pocket cost of supplying this energy. Consumption Energy Imbalance Consumption Energy Imbalance is the difference between the Pre-Schedule and the Customer's actual metered consumption. When such a difference arises, the Transmission Provider's Control Area will react accordingly. Specifically, if consumption is greater than the Pre-Schedule, the Transmission Provider will automatically supply power to make up for the deficiency. If consumption is less than the Pre-Schedule, the Transmission Provider will automatically back down contracted generation by the amount of oversupply. Consumption Energy Imbalance will be traded as follows: (i)If ES s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption is greater than the Pre-Schedule, ES will pay the Company the Marginal Hourly Price. (ii) If ES s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption is less than the Pre-Schedule, the Company will pay the ES the Marginal Hourly Price. Schedule 5, Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service5 Spinning Reserve Service is needed to serve load immediately in the event of a system contingency. Spinning Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The ES must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Spinning Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Spinning Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $.00061/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $.00069/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $.00069/kWh Rate Schedule C-A (commercial/industrial): $.00072/kWh Rate Schedule CSH (commercial): $.00072/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $.22/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $.208/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL, SL, EMU and MU (street and area lighting): $.00068/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $.078/kW Hagerstown & Frederick: $.00068/kWh Eastalco: $.71/kW Schedule 6, Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service6 Supplemental Reserve Service is needed to serve load in the event of a system contingency; however, it is not available immediately to serve load but rather within a short period of time. Supplemental Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line but unloaded, by quick-start generation or by interruptible load. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The ES must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Supplemental Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the ES are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $.00054/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $.00062/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $.00062/kWh Rate Schedule C-A (commercial/industrial): $.00064/kWh Rate Schedule CSH (commercial): $.00064/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $.19/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $.185/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL, SL, EMU and MU (street and area lighting): $.00058/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $.070/kW Hagerstown & Frederick: $.00058/kWh Eastalco: $.63/kW Schedule 9, Real Power Transmission Loss Service7 Real Power Transmission Loss Service is needed to serve the real power lost when an ES transmits power through, from, within, and into the Control Area. The ES is responsible for securing and delivering Real Power Transmission Losses. For convenience, combined transmission and distribution loss amounts that will be applied when a customer takes service from facilities at voltages below those of the transmission system are as set forth below. These voltages are stated in ranges that are consistent with The Potomac Edison Company s retail rate schedules in Maryland. The combined transmission and distribution line losses for Secondary, Primary, Subtransmission with transformer charges, Subtransmission and Transmission voltage levels shall be calculated by multiplying hourly kWh sales delivered to customer(s) served at these voltage levels by the applicable line loss factor. Line loss factors are time-differentiated as on-peak and off-peak for each voltage classification. The on-peak line loss factors apply to the hours ended 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. The off-peak line loss factors apply to all remaining hours. The applicable on-peak and off-peak line loss factors are: Voltage served On peak line losses Off peak line losses Secondary (<1kv) 9.513% 8.671% Primary (1kv to l5kv) 7.542 6.893 Subtransmission (15kv to 100kv) 3.742 3.458 Transmission (>100kv) 2.245 2.028 The Transmission Provider will make available the mapping of the voltage line loss factors to the respective rate schedules (rate codes) on the Company website. NETWORK OPERATING AGREEMENT Section 4.4 Scheduling of Network Integration Transmission Service All scheduling practices and schedules submitted by the ES will comply with applicable North American Electric Reliability Council (or its successor organization) criteria. ES shall submit all schedules electronically via NERC Tag. As used herein, an Energy Schedule for Reservations of Network Integrated Transmission Service (scheduled daily), shall refer to the Eligible Customer(s) Schedule provided by Customers' ES for the receipt and delivery of energy with the Transmission Provider. The Energy Schedule may be communicated in whole megawatts to the Transmission Provider via an electronic or dynamic schedule. Electronic Schedules Energy Schedules for Eligible Customer(s) Network Integration Transmission Service must be submitted via NERC Tag by the ES to the Transmission Provider no later than 1:00 p.m., one (1) business day before the delivery of power. A business day is a weekday excepting Company holidays. Scheduling changes, submitted via NERC Tag, to accommodate changes in generation sources will be permitted up to twenty (20) minutes, before the start of the next clock hour or the next half hour provided that the Delivering Party and Receiving Party are all in agreement with the schedule modification. The Transmission Provider will furnish to the Delivering Party's system operator, hour-to-hour schedules equal to those furnished by the Receiving Party (unless reduced for losses) and shall deliver the capacity and energy provided by such schedules. Should the ES, Delivering Party or Receiving Party revise or terminate any Energy Schedule, such party shall immediately notify the Transmission Provider, and the Transmission Provider shall have the right to adjust accordingly the Energy Schedule for capacity and energy to be received and to be delivered. Schedule changes to accommodate 30 minute interruptible loads will also be permitted. Such schedule changes shall be provided by the ES to the Transmission Provider as soon as possible after Eligible Customer or ES has been notified of the requirement to drop the interruptible load, but in no event later than 20 minutes before the start of the interruption. The ES shall specifically tell the Transmission Provider when schedule changes are attributable to 30-minute interruptible loads. In such instances, ES will not be penalized for Supply Energy Imbalance arising from schedule changes due to interruptible loads. However, failure of a customer to drop the interruptible portion of its load will be reflected in the Consumption Energy Imbalance billed to the ES. Section 5.0 Default If the Eligible Customer or ES fails to perform consistent with the terms and conditions of this agreement, then the Eligible Customer or ES will be deemed to be in default and service may be suspended immediately, subject to a filing of a notice of termination with the FERC, provided however, in the event the Transmission Customer or ES fails, for any reason other than a billing dispute as described below, to make payment to the Transmission Provider on or before the due date as described above, and such failure of payment is not corrected within thirty (30) calendar days after the Transmission Provider notifies the Eligible Customer or ES to cure such failure, a default by the Eligible Customer of ES shall be deemed to exist. Upon the occurrence of a default, the Transmission Provider may initiate a proceeding with the Commission to terminate service but shall not terminate service until the Commission so approves any such request; provided however, that in the event that a state required retail access program provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another ES, then the Transmission Provider may, upon default by an ES immediately terminate service to the defaulting ES for the load of such end-use customers. ATTACHMENT H Annual Transmission Revenue Requirement For Network Integration Transmission Service For Retail Transmission Service8 Charges for Network Integration Transmission Service shall be determined by aggregating the ES s Eligible Customer(s) Retail Transmission Service charges. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Network Integration Transmission Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing months by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): All kWh $.00396/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): Minimum Bills $.36/bill Minimum kW $.14/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-350) $.00580/kWh 2nd Block (351-700) $.00461/kWh 3rd Block (over 700) $.00216/kWh When Customer requires capacity over 7.5 kilowatts, the second energy block shall be increased 53 kilowatt-hours for each one-half kilowatt of capacity required in excess of 7.5 kilowatts. The third energy block shall then include all kilowatt-hours in excess of the first and second energy blocks as adjusted. Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a 30-minute interval during a billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): Minimum Bills $.34/bill Minimum kW $.19/kW Demand Rate (kW) 1st Block (0-7.5) $0/kW 2nd Block (over 7.5) $.24/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-700) $.00440/kWh 2nd Block (over 700) $.00214/kWh Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a thirty (30) minute interval during the billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the previous twelve months. For connections without a demand meter, the kilowatt capacity required shall be defined as the number of kilowatt-hours used in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) of the highest kilowatt-hours used in any of the previous twelve months, divided by 250. Rate Schedule C-A (commercial/industrial): Minimum Bills $1.30/bill Minimum kW $.14/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-350) $.00725/kWh 2nd Block (351-700) $.00632/kWh 3rd Block (over 700) $.00337/kWh When Customer requires capacity over 7.5 kilowatts, the second energy block shall be increased 37 kilowatt-hours for each one-half kilowatt of capacity required in excess of 7.5 kilowatts. The third energy block shall then include all kilowatt-hours in excess of the first and second energy blocks as adjusted. Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a 30-minute interval during a billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedule CSH (commercial): Schedule Minimum $1.30/bill Minimum kW $.14/kW All other kWh $.00381/kWh Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a 30-minute interval during a billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): Demand Rate (kW) Standby Demand $.30/kW kW at Minimum $.43/kW 1st Block (0-500) $.68/kW 2nd Block (over 500) $.67/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-100,000) $.00159/kWh 2nd Block (over 100,000) $.00133/kWh Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a 30-minute interval during a billing period, but not less than 50 kilowatts. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be one-half (1/2) of the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): Demand Rate (kW) All kW $.574/kW Energy Rate (kWh) All kWh $.00118/kWh Kilowatt billing capacity during a billing period shall be the highest of: 1. The maximum 30-minute metered kilowatt capacity, or 2. For Customers contracting for "off-peak" service, the billing demand for any month shall be the maximum demand measured during "on-peak" hours plus 25 percent of the amount that the maximum demand measured during "off-peak" hours exceeds the maximum "on-peak" demand. "Off-Peak" hours shall be from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. daily plus all hours of Sunday. Customer will be responsible for the cost of additional facilities required to furnish "off-peak" capacity in excess of "on-peak" capacity. 3. 60% of the maximum instantaneous kilowatt capacity. However, the "Billing Capacity" for any month shall not be less than the highest of: (a) 5,000 kilowatts, or, (b) 75% of the kilowatt capacity specified in the Electric Service Agreement, or, (c) 75% of the highest "Billing Capacity" established during the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL, SL, EMU and MU (street and area lighting): All kWh $.00079/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): Firm Standby Power 1st Block (0-100 kW) $.349/kW 2nd Block (over 100 kW) $.327/kW Interruptible Standby Power 1st Block (0-100 kW) $.332/kW 2nd Block (over 100 kW) $.309/kW Maintenance Power All kW $.309/kW Energy Rate (kWh) All kWh $.00055/kWh Hagerstown & Frederick: Energy Charge (kWh) All kWh $.00079/kWh Eastalco: Demand Rate (kW) System Demand $1.23/kW Additional Capacity $11,989.47/month Reactive kVA Rate Billing kVAR $.15/kVAR Energy Rate (kWh) Incremental Energy $.00215/kWh The retail transmission rates for purposes of the Network Integration Transmission Service (stated above) are shown in The Potomac Edison Company s Maryland rate tariffs and are based upon OATT rates on file with the Commission. These rates are based on an annual transmission revenue requirement (without Ancillary Services) for the Potomac Edison Company s Retail Customers of $22,432,056. The amount listed above shall be effective until amended by the Transmission Provider or modified by the Commission. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties intending to be legally bound, have caused this Schedule 11-Retail Transmission Service to be executed by their authorized officials. Electric Generation Supplier Transmission Provider Company____________________ Allegheny Power By_________________________ By_________________________ Name_______________________ Name_______________________ Title________________________ Title________________________ Date________________________ Date_______________________
record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 12 TABLE OF CONTENTS I. Definitions--------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1 Certified Supplier (CS) ------------------------------------------------ 2 Designated Agent--------------------------------------------------------- 3 Marginal Hourly Price-------------------------------------------------- II. Terms and Conditions------------------------------------------------------------------- 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers------ 7.1 Billing Procedure-------------------------------------------------------- 7.3 Customer Default-------------------------------------------------------- Section 11 Creditworthiness------------------------------------------------------------------ Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service----------------------------------- Section 28.4 Secondary Service---------------------------------------------------------------- Section 28.5 Real Power Losses---------------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service----------------------------------- Section 29.2 Application Procedures----------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities----------------------------------------------------- Section 34 Rates and Charges---------------------------------------------------------------- Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee------------------------------------------------ Schedule 4 Energy Imbalance Service------------------------------------------------------ Supply Energy Imbalance------------------------------------------------------ Consumption Energy Imbalance---------------------------------------------- Schedule 9 Real Power Transmission Loss Service-------------------------------------- Network Operating Agreement----------------------------------------------------------------- Section 4.4 Scheduling of Network Integration Transmission Service---------------- Section 5.0 Default---------------------------------------------------------------------------- Attachment H Annual Transmission Revenue Requirement for Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service------------------------------------------------------------------------- RETAIL TRANSMISSION SERVICE - OHIO Retail transmission services pursuant to the Commission s Order Nos. 888, 888-A and B, 889 and 889-A and B shall be made available under this Schedule 12 to unbundled retail customers in the state of Ohio with the right to choose their electric suppliers. Service shall be provided according to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Tariff which is hereby incorporated herein except as modified below. I. Definitions 1.Certified Supplier (CS) shall mean a person or corporation, (including municipal corporations which choose to provide service outside their municipal limits as prescribed by state law), broker or marketer, aggregator, scheduling coordinator, or any other entity selling to end-use customers (including an electric distribution company providing service as a provider of last resort) electricity or related services utilizing the jurisdictional transmission and distribution facilities of an electric distribution company. 2.Designated Agent shall mean any entity that performs actions or functions on behalf of the Transmission Provider, an Eligible Customer, or the Transmission Customer required under the Tariff. 3.Marginal Hourly Price shall mean the price at which Consumption Energy Imbalance will be traded. The price is the Transmission Provider s out-of-pocket cost for energy purchased during the hour in which the Consumption Energy Imbalance occurs. Terms and Conditions Retail Transmission Services shall be provided pursuant to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Service Tariff, as amended ( OATT ) except as modified below. The CS(s) shall act as a Designated Agent for an Eligible Customer(s), unless otherwise indicated below. Section 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers. Eligible Customers classified as retail customers taking unbundled transmission service pursuant to a state requirement that the Transmission Provider offer the transmission service, or pursuant to a voluntary offer of such service by the Transmission Provider with a contract term of one-year or more have the right to continue to take transmission service from the Transmission Provider when the contract expires, rolls over or is renewed. This transmission reservation priority is independent of whether the existing customer continues to purchase capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider or elects to purchase capacity and energy from another CS. If at the end of the contract term the Transmission Provider s Transmission System cannot accommodate all of the requests for transmission service, the existing firm service customer must agree to accept a contract term at least equal to a competing request by any new Eligible Customer and to pay the current just and reasonable rate, as approved by the Commission, for such service. This transmission reservation priority for existing retail firm service customers is an ongoing right that may be exercised at the end of all firm contract terms of one-year or longer. Section 7.1 Billing Procedure Within a reasonable time after the Transmission Customer s meter cycle read date, the Transmission Provider should submit an invoice to the Transmission Customer for the charges for all services furnished under the Tariff during the preceding month, except that charges for retail Energy Imbalance, if applicable, shall be charged and billed to the CS. The Transmission Provider shall charge the CS for any Supply Energy Imbalance service rendered to the CS during the calendar month and for an estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance as related to the calendar month. Approximately 60 days later, the CS shall also be billed an adjustment for Consumption Energy Imbalance after all Eligible Customer(s) energy usage occurring during the calendar month is collected from meter readings and processed. This adjustment will be determined as the difference between such estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance and the Consumption Energy Imbalance determined after meter data collection. The invoices shall be paid by the CS within twenty (20) days of receipt. All payments shall be made in immediately available funds payable to the Transmission Provider, or by wire transfer to a bank named by the Transmission Provider. Section 7.3 Customer Default In the event the CS fails for any reason other than a billing dispute as described below, to make payment to the Transmission Provider on or before the due date as described above, and such failure of payment is not corrected within thirty (30) calendar days after the Transmission Provider notifies the CS to cure such failure, a default by the CS shall be deemed to exist. Upon the occurrence of a default, the Transmission Provider may initiate a proceeding with the Commission to terminate service but shall not terminate service until the Commission so approves any such request; provided however, that in the event that a state required retail access program provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another CS, then the Transmission Provider may, upon default by a CS, immediately terminate service to the defaulting CS for the load of such end-use customers. In the event of a billing dispute between the Transmission Provider and the CS, the Transmission Provider will continue to provide service under the Service Agreement as long as the CS (i) continues to make all payments not in dispute, and (ii) pays into an independent escrow account the portion of the invoice in dispute, pending resolution of such dispute. If the CS fails to meet these two requirements for continuation of service, then the Transmission Provider may provide notice to the CS of its intention to suspend service in sixty (60) days, in accordance with Commission policy, or in the case of a state required retail access program that provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another CS, immediately terminate transmission service to the defaulting CS as provided above. Section 11 Creditworthiness For the purpose of determining the ability of the Transmission Customer or CS to meet its obligations related to service hereunder, the Transmission Provider may require reasonable credit review procedures. The Transmission Customer or CS will be considered creditworthy if (1) the Transmission Customer s or CS s long-term unsecured debt securities are, and remain, rated a minimum of BBB or Baa2 by Standard & Poor s or Moody s, respectively, (b) the Transmission Customer or CS either prepays for service or provides an irrevocable standby letter of credit issued by a domestic or Canadian bank with a minimum A (Standard & Poor s or Dominion) or A2 (Moody s) long-term unsecured debt rating, for an amount equal to the sum of the charges pursuant to this Tariff for the shorter of (i) the three (3) individual months when such charges would be greatest, or (ii) the term of the Service Agreement based on mutually agreeable load factors pursuant to this Tariff, (c) the Transmission Customer or CS has, as determined by Allegheny Power in its sole discretion, a qualified long-term payment history with Allegheny Power, or (d) the Transmission Customer s or CS s parent company, in a form satisfactory to Allegheny Power, guarantees responsibility for all financial obligations associated with the Service Agreement and such parent company conforms to the minimum ratings specified above. Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service The Transmission Provider will provide firm transmission service over its Transmission System to the CS on behalf of its Eligible Customers for the delivery of capacity and energy from its designated Network Resources to service its Network Loads on a basis that is comparable to the Transmission Provider s use of the Transmission System to reliably serve its Native Load Customers. The CS must designate its Network Resources via NERC Tag by 1:00 p.m., one (1) business day before the delivery of power. Firm Available Transmission Capability will be awarded on a first-come, first-serve basis based on the receipt time of the NERC Tag. Section 28.4 Secondary Service The CS on behalf of its Eligible Customers may use the Transmission Provider s Transmission System to deliver energy to its Network Loads from resources that have not been designated as Network Resources. The CS shall request to change generation sources to non-Network Resources via NERC Tag. Such energy shall be transmitted, on an as-available-basis, at no additional charge. Deliveries from resources other than Network Resources will have a higher priority than any Non-Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service under Part II of the Tariff. Section 28.5 Real Power Losses Real Power Losses are associated with all transmission service. The CS is responsible for supplying losses associated with its Eligible Customer(s). The applicable Real Power Loss factors are as listed below in Schedule 9 of this Schedule 12. Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service Subject to the terms and conditions of Part III of the Tariff, the Transmission Provider will provide Network Integration Transmission Service to any Eligible Customer, provided that (i) the Eligible Customer completes an Application for service as provided under Part III of the Tariff, as required (ii) the Eligible Customer and the Transmission Provider complete the technical arrangements set forth in Sections 29.3 and 29.4, (iii) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Service Agreement with the Commission, and (iv) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Network Operating Agreement with the Commission pursuant to Attachment G. The Eligible Customer and CS shall be bound by the Terms and Conditions of the OATT including this Schedule 12. Section 29.2 Application Procedures An Eligible Customer (or a Designated Agent) requesting service under Part III of the Tariff may be required to submit an Application, with a deposit approximating the charge for one month of service, to the Transmission Provider as far as possible in advance of the month in which service is to commence. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Transmission Provider may, on a non-discriminatory basis, waive the requirement that a deposit accompany an Application where the Eligible Customer has established its creditworthiness pursuant to Section 11 of this Tariff and is not in default in its obligation under this Section 7.3 of this Tariff at the time of Application. The Transmission Provider will bill the Eligible Customer for any reasonable costs incurred by the Transmission Provider in connection with its review of the Application. Such bill will contain a complete accounting of all costs included. Unless subject to the procedures in Section 2, Completed Applications for Network Integration Transmission Service will be assigned a priority according to the date and time the Application is received, with the earliest Application receiving the highest priority. Applications should be submitted by entering the information listed below on the Transmission Provider s OASIS. Prior to implementation of the Transmission Provider s OASIS, a Completed Application may be submitted by (i) transmitting the required information to the Transmission Provider by telefax, or (ii) providing the information by telephone over the Transmission Provider s time recorded telephone line. Each of these methods will provide a time-stamped record for establishing the service priority of the Application. A Completed Application shall provide all of the information included in 18 CFR 2.20 including but not limited to the following: (i)The identity, address, telephone number and facsimile number of the party requesting service; (ii) A statement that the party requesting service is, or will be upon commencement of service, an Eligible Customer under the Tariff; (iii) A description of the Network Load at each delivery point. This description should separately identify and provide the Eligible Customer s best estimate of the total loads to be served at each transmission voltage level, and the load to be served from each Transmission Provider substation at the same transmission voltage level. The description should include a ten (10) year forecast of summer and winter load and resource requirements beginning with the first year after the service is scheduled to commence; (iv) The amount and location of any interruptible loads included in the Network Load. This shall include the summer and winter capacity requirements for each interruptible load (had such load not been interruptible), that portion of the load subject to interruption, the conditions under which an interruption can be implemented and any limitations on the amount and frequency of interruptions. An Eligible Customer should identify the amount of interruptible customer load (if any) included in the 10 year load forecast provided in response to (iii) above; (v) A description of Network Resources (current and 10-year projection), which shall include, for each Network Resource: Unit size and amount of capacity from that unit to be designated as Network Resource VAR capability (both leading and lagging) of all generators Operating restrictions Any periods of restricted operations throughout the year Maintenance schedules Minimum loading level of unit Normal operating level of unit Any must-run unit designations required for system reliability or contract reasons Approximate variable generating cost ($MWH) for redispatch computations Arrangement governing sale and delivery of power to third parties from generating facilities located in the Transmission Provider Control Area, where only a portion of unit output is designated as a Network Resource Description of purchased power designated as a Network Resource including source of supply, Control Area location, transmission arrangements and delivery point(s) to the Transmission Provider s Transmission System; (vi) Description of Eligible Customer s transmission system: Load flow and stability data, such as real and reactive parts of the load, lines, transformers, reactive devices and load type, including normal and emergency ratings of all transmission equipment in a load flow format compatible with that used by the Transmission Provider Operating restrictions needed for reliability Operating guides employed by system operators Contractual restrictions or committed uses of the Eligible Customers transmission system, other than the Eligible Customer s Network Loads and Resources Location of Network Resources described in subsection (v) above 10 year projection of system expansions or upgrades Transmission System maps that include any proposed expansions or upgrades Thermal ratings of Eligible Customer s Control Area ties with other Control Areas; and (vii) Service Commencement Date and the term of the requested Network Integration Transmission Service. The minimum term for Network Integration Transmission Service is one year. Unless the Parties agree to a different time frame, the Transmission Provider must acknowledge the request within ten (10) days of receipt. The acknowledgement must include a date by which a response, including a Service Agreement, will be sent to the Eligible Customer. If an Application fails to meet the requirements of this section, the Transmission Provider shall notify the Eligible Customer requesting service within fifteen (15) days of receipt and specify the reasons for such failure. Wherever possible, the Transmission Provider will attempt to remedy deficiencies in the Application through informal communications with the Eligible Customer. If such efforts are unsuccessful, the Transmission Provider shall return the Application without prejudice to the Eligible Customer filing a new or revised Application that fully complies with the requirements of this section. The Eligible Customer will be assigned a new priority consistent with the date of the new or revised Application. The Transmission Provider shall treat this information consistent with the standards of conduct contained in Part 37 of the Commission's regulations. Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities The provision of Network Integration Transmission Service shall be conditioned upon the Eligible Customer's constructing, maintaining and operating the facilities on its side of each delivery point or interconnection necessary to reliably deliver capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider's transmission system to the Eligible Customer or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. The Eligible Customer shall be solely responsible for constructing or installing all facilities on the Eligible Customer's side of each such delivery point or interconnection or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. Section 34 Rates and Charges Transmission Customer charges shall be in accordance with OATT rates and charges except as listed below. The CS is responsible for paying the following charges on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). Charges for Energy Imbalance Service Supply Energy Imbalance Charges for Supply Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between a Pre-schedule and associated Schedule(s). Supply Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 12. Consumption Energy Imbalance Charges for Consumption Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between the Pre-Schedule and the CS s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption. Consumption Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 12. Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee A Network Operating Committee (Committee) may be established to coordinate operating criteria for the Parties' respective responsibilities for Eligible Customer(s) under the Network Operating Agreement. Each CS serving Eligible Customer(s) within the Transmission Provider's Control Area shall be entitled to have at least one representative on the Committee. The Committee shall meet from time to time as need requires.
