In the event the Parties are unable to agree on the reason why the Maximum Output was exceeded, they shall resolve their dispute according to the terms of Article 22. Until AP has completed the study(ies) and a new Maximum Output has been established, GENERATOR shall abide the Maximum Output specified in Article 1.29. In the event that power deliveries exceed the Maximum Output as defined in Article 1.29 and AP incurs costs due to such deliveries, GENERATOR shall compensate AP for such costs. 2.8 GENERATOR shall be responsible for obtaining capacity and/or energy to satisfy its power requirements and shall demonstrate to AP s reasonable satisfaction that such arrangements have been made. AP shall reasonably cooperate with GENERATOR with respect to such agreements. Notwithstanding its purchase of power requirements from a Third Party, GENERATOR may be responsible for its allocable share of any competitive transition charge or similar charges or surcharges authorized by any Governmental Authority having jurisdiction. In the event GENERATOR elects to purchase its power requirements from a Third Party, AP may require additional metering equipment in order to calculate the transition charge or similar charges or surcharges authorized by Governmental Authority having jurisdiction. GENERATOR may purchase its power requirements from AP under an applicable tariff or agreement. AP shall have no obligation to supply GENERATOR energy for resale unless otherwise agreed upon between the Parties. In the event the GENERATOR is interconnected to AP s distribution system and the transmission system, GENERATOR must install break-before-make transfer switches. At no time shall GENERATOR purposefully interconnect its generation to the distribution system. GENERATOR shall not be interconnected to more than one point of interconnection to the Transmission System simultaneously. GENERATOR s unit(s) shall not be interconnected to the Transmission System and to any other electrical system simultaneously. Appropriate protective relaying and interlocks must be installed, which may include but are not limited to voltage sensing, reverse power flow and synch check relay and control schemes. If GENERATOR s Project is unable to meet the specifications in this Article 2.8, other specifications may be agreed to by both Parties which shall be included in Exhibit H hereto. 2.9 In the event that AP is subject to any penalties for failure to meet local, regional or national reliability standards, GENERATOR shall share in the responsibilities prescribed by the penalty to the extent that and in proportion to GENERATOR s contribution to such penalties that result from its failure to perform its obligations under this Agreement. 2.10 Energy shall be scheduled per the OATT by the GENERATOR or its customer as appropriate either from the Project or from a pool of generation within AP to the Transmission System for redelivery by a transmission customer of AP. The receipt point of energy to the Transmission System shall be the Interconnection Point. This Article shall not apply to schedules with points of delivery within AP s Control Area. If a scheduled amount so established is not met for any hour, a generation supply imbalance will exist for that hour. Pooling of generation within the AP control area for scheduling purposes shall only be an option for as long as it is legitimate to do so under FERC OATT or subsequent transmission tariffs or NERC policies. In the event GENERATOR sells the output of the Project to a transmission customer of AP at the Interconnection Point, GENERATOR shall be obligated for generator supply imbalance pursuant to this Article. If the actual delivered output (pool or Project as appropriate) is less than the scheduled amount in a given hour, an undersupply imbalance will exist for that hour, and if the actual delivered output (pool or Project as appropriate) exceeds the scheduled amount in a given hour, an oversupply imbalance will exist for that hour. In the event of an undersupply imbalance, GENERATOR shall pay to AP the greater of 110% of AP s Out of Pocket Costs or $100/MWh for the replacement energy. In the event of an oversupply imbalance, GENERATOR shall not be compensated, unless the oversupply imbalance occurs as a result of instructions communicated to GENERATOR by AP s OC pursuant to this Agreement or under obligations that may be imposed on GENERATOR pursuant to other agreements with AP. The GENERATOR shall not be subject to imbalance charges specified in this Article 2.10 for the following conditions: 1) GENERATOR elects to operate its entire Project in the Automatic Dispatch Mode, as specified in Article 4.13 A.1, as long as GENERATOR operates within the regulation bands set for the unit. 2) GENERATOR is following AP s directive for changes in the operating levels of the units of the Project during Emergency Conditions that are not caused by the Project, during the provision of System Restoration Services or as a result of other operation of the Project in excess of the requirements of this Agreement at the request of AP. 3) GENERATOR is operating in accordance with obligations that may be imposed on GENERATOR pursuant to other agreements with AP. 4) The entire output of the Project is Dynamically Scheduled. In the event that AP incurs a penalty charge as a result of any generation supply imbalance, GENERATOR shall also reimburse AP for such penalty charge to the extent that and in proportion to GENERATOR s contribution to such penalty charge that result from its failure to perform its obligations under this Agreement. In the event AP adopts another methodology to handle Generator Imbalance that is accepted by the FERC pursuant to Section 205 of the Federal Power Act, this Agreement shall be amended to include such methodology in accordance with Article 24.2. 2.11 During Minimum Loading Conditions, and if GENERATOR is in imbalance relative to the schedule set pursuant to Article 2.10, AP may require GENERATOR to adjust its delivered energy to match the schedule. In the event GENERATOR can not adjust deliveries to its schedule after notice to do so from the Control Area and AP s Control Area still has an imbalance AP may require GENERATOR to adjust its delivered energy within 15 minutes to the schedule or shut down its unit(s) in order to help balance AP s Control Area. 2.12 (a) Due to the interconnected nature of electric power systems, the interconnection of the Project to the Transmission System may have effects on other utility systems ("Affected Systems"). Good Utility Practice requires AP to share its studies relating to the Interconnection with interconnected systems which may be Affected Systems. To the extent required by FERC interconnection policy, orders or applicable laws and regulations, GENERATOR shall be responsible for entering into such arrangements with Affected Systems as are necessary to address any effects of the Project's interconnection with the AP Transmission System on Affected Systems ("Third Party Impacts"). In the event AP or Affected Systems' studies determine that the interconnection and energizing of the Project would adversely impact an Affected System and/or interface(s) between the Affected System and AP, the adverse impact must be addressed in accordance with the provisions of (b) below. (b) In the event that any of AP's or Affected Systems' studies relating to the interconnection indicate that upgrades are needed on the AP System and/or on an Affected System solely to allow interconnection of the Project to AP Transmission System, AP and/or GENERATOR agree to (i) negotiate, in conjunction with such Affected System, to achieve an arrangement satisfactory to GENERATOR, to AP, and to such Affected System that is consistent with FERC policy and applicable laws and regulations and to present any mutually agreed upon arrangement to the FERC for acceptance or (ii) if a resolution mutually acceptable to AP and GENERATOR and Affected System is not achieved, either AP or GENERATOR may bring the matter before the FERC by an appropriate filing. Pending resolution by the FERC of a filing made under (i) or (ii) above, AP shall not be required to complete the interconnection and allow the GENERATOR's Project to be interconnected and synchronized with the AP System until those Third Party Impact upgrades are in service that if not in service would as indicated in the AP or Affected Systems studies cause an Emergency Condition, provided, however, that AP shall be required to complete the interconnection and allow the GENERATOR s Project to be interconnected and synchronized with the AP System if the AP or Affected Systems studies do not indicate that completing the interconnection and allowing the Project to interconnect and synchronize with the AP System prior to installation of the Third Party Impact upgrades would cause an Emergency Condition. Except as otherwise required by Applicable Laws and Regulation or orders of the FERC, AP shall not be required to implement operational fixes to alleviate or manage Emergency Condition(s) pending installation of the Third Party Impact upgrades. GENERATOR agrees to indemnify and hold harmless AP, its directors, officers, agents, representatives, and employees against and from any charges or assessment by any Affected System against AP accepted by the FERC in order to mitigate any Third Party Impacts to the extent that the FERC determines such charges or assessments to be the responsibility of GENERATOR. In addition, if upgrades are required to be placed on AP's system as a result of Third Party Impacts, GENERATOR shall compensate AP for all costs associated with such upgrades that are determined by the FERC to be the responsibility of GENERATOR. AP shall promptly notify GENERATOR of any claim or assertion by an Affected System of Third Party Impacts. (c)AP agrees that so long as GENERATOR complies with the provisions of this Agreement with regard to payment to AP for installation of AP s Interconnection Facilities or the System Upgrades, AP shall not delay commencement or prosecution of the construction of such facilities during the negotiations contemplated by subsection (b) above or while any filing made pursuant to Section 2.12(b) is pending before the FERC. ARTICLE 3 System Restoration 3.1 In an Emergency Condition, GENERATOR shall cooperate fully with AP s efforts for System Restoration. GENERATOR shall make System Restoration Services available to the Control Area in order to start generators in AP s Control Area before making such services available directly to generators or entities outside of AP s Control Area. Within sixty (60) minutes of AP s notification to GENERATOR of System Restoration conditions, GENERATOR shall have Qualified Personnel available at the Project. AP may elect to perform periodic testing of AP s System Restoration plan. GENERATOR shall cooperate with AP on such efforts. Upon prior reasonable notice, AP may require all applicable projects to have Qualified Personnel participate in AP s System Restoration meetings. AP will compensate GENERATOR for its Out of Pocket Costs of providing or testing any level of System Restoration Services. In the event GENERATOR incurs penalties from any applicable Governmental Authority due to providing System Restoration Services at the request of AP, AP shall reimburse GENERATOR those costs to the extent they have not been waived by the governmental authority. 3.2 The Project does not have System Restoration Capability. If found mutually desirable, AP and GENERATOR may negotiate costs for installation of additional hardware that may enhance the Project s ability to provide System Restoration Capability. 3.3 In the event AP has an FERC accepted tariff for System Restoration Services, GENERATOR shall be compensated at the rates set forth in such tariff; provided, however, that in the event FERC accepts a GENERATOR tariff for such services, the Parties shall negotiate on which tariff will be used for this service. ARTICLE 4 Operations and Maintenance ( O&M ) 4.1 GENERATOR shall pay AP in accordance with Article 11 for all operation and maintenance expenses reasonably incurred by AP in accordance with Good Utility Practice to operate and maintain AP s Interconnection Facilities shown on Exhibit D. AP shall operate and maintain the System Upgrades at its own cost and expense. 4.2 GENERATOR shall own, operate and maintain at GENERATOR s sole expense its Project in a manner consistent with Good Utility Practice to prevent degradation of voltage or services of AP s Transmission System. GENERATOR s equipment shall conform to industry standards. Industry standards may include but are not limited to those for harmonic distortion and voltage fluctuation. GENERATOR shall, upon the reasonable request of AP and consistent with Good Utility Practice and the Design Limits, test, calibrate, verify or adjust the voltage regulator control settings as necessary to meet the performance requirements of the Transmission System. 4.3 (a) If AP reasonably determines that any of GENERATOR's Interconnection Facility and/or Project fails to perform in a manner consistent with Good Utility Practice or this Agreement, or GENERATOR has failed to perform proper testing or maintenance of GENERATOR s Interconnection Facility and/or Project in accordance with Good Utility Practice or this Agreement, AP shall give GENERATOR written notice (except in Emergency Conditions) to take corrective action. AP shall provide such written notice as soon as practicable upon such determination. GENERATOR shall take such corrective action consistent with Good Utility Practice and the requirements of this Agreement. If GENERATOR fails to initiate corrective action promptly, and if in AP's reasonable judgment leaving GENERATOR's facilities connected with AP's Transmission System would create and/or exacerbate an Emergency Condition, AP may, with as much prior verbal notification to GENERATOR as practicable, open the connection between GENERATOR and AP until appropriate corrective actions have been completed by GENERATOR, as verified by AP. AP s judgment with regard to an interruption of service under this paragraph shall be made pursuant to Good Utility Practice. In the case of such interruption, AP shall immediately confer with GENERATOR regarding the conditions causing such interruption and its recommendation concerning timely correction thereof. GENERATOR shall take appropriate corrective action before Project can re-connect with the Transmission System. (b) If GENERATOR reasonably determines that any of AP s Interconnection Facilities fails to perform in a manner consistent with Good Utility Practice or this Agreement, or AP has failed to perform proper testing or maintenance of its Interconnection Facilities in accordance with Good Utility Practice or this Agreement, GENERATOR shall give AP written notice to take corrective action (except in Emergency Conditions during which GENERATOR may provide AP with verbal notification). GENERATOR shall provide such written notice as soon as practicable upon such determination. AP shall take such corrective action consistent with Good Utility Practice and the requirements of this Agreement. If AP fails to initiate corrective action promptly, and if in GENERATOR s reasonable judgment leaving the Project connected with the Transmission System would create and/or exacerbate an Emergency Condition, GENERATOR may, with as much prior verbal notification to AP as practicable, open the connection between GENERATOR and AP until appropriate corrective actions have been completed by AP, as verified by GENERATOR. GENERATOR s judgment with regard to an interruption of service under this paragraph shall be made pursuant to Good Utility Practice. In the case of such interruption, GENERATOR shall immediately confer with AP regarding the conditions causing such interruption and its recommendation concerning timely correction thereof. AP shall take appropriate corrective action so that Project can re-connect with the Transmission System. 4.4 Any protective relay control system that causes any AP breaker or GENERATOR breaker connected to an AP bus to operate shall be maintained and tested in accordance with the provisions of this Article 4. 4.5 AP shall, at GENERATOR s expense and in accordance with Good Utility Practice, own, operate, maintain and test AP s system protection equipment consisting of but not limited to protective relays, power circuit breakers, current transformers and potential transformers as shown in Exhibit D that provide protection for the Transmission System. GENERATOR shall, in accordance with Good Utility Practice, own, operate, maintain and test the GENERATOR S system protection equipment consisting of but not limited to protective relays, power circuit breakers, current transformers and potential transformers as shown in Exhibit E. The Parties shall maintain, and, as necessary, upgrade their respective protective relay systems, and in the case of GENERATOR, any synchronization system equipment associated with the Interconnection Point, in accordance with Good Utility Practice, and shall provide the other Party with access to copies of operation and maintenance manuals and test records for all relay equipment, and in the case of GENERATOR, any synchronization system equipment. AP shall have the right, using Good Utility Practice, to review and approve all synchronizing procedures necessary to establish and maintain proper and safe interconnection between GENERATOR's Project and the Transmission System, which approval shall not unreasonably be withheld. 4.6 The Parties shall test their respective relays associated with the Interconnection Point for correct calibration and operation in accordance with Good Utility Practice. Complete functional testing of both Parties relay protection schemes shall be coordinated so as to be performed at the same time. Repairs or modifications to the protective relay systems which result in complete testing and functional verification of all relay systems associated with Interconnection Point will be considered as a complete ECAR test and therefore shall restart the normal ECAR maintenance and testing cycle. 4.7 GENERATOR shall bear the cost of all relay calibration and functional testing associated with GENERATOR s Interconnection Facility and Project to the extent such calibration and testing are consistent with Good Utility Practice. All such testing must be performed by a Qualified Personnel selected by GENERATOR. In addition, AP may arrange with GENERATOR for an annual, visual inspection of the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facility and Project and associated maintenance records. Such inspections and review shall occur during normal business hours. AP shall provide reasonable notice for such requested inspections or reviews. GENERATOR shall use reasonable efforts to accommodate the requested dates. Upon completion of all relay calibration testing and relay functional testing, GENERATOR shall make available copies of all test reports for review by AP. AP shall review test reports and certify that the relay system's tests and settings as shown on such test reports have been done in accordance with the equipment specifications and Good Utility Practice. Such test and certification shall be signed by Qualified Personnel competent to perform protective relay system design and analysis. 4.8 Each Party shall operate the Interconnection Facilities in a safe and efficient manner and in accordance with all Applicable Laws and Regulations, and Good Utility Practice, and otherwise in accordance with the terms of this Agreement. GENERATOR shall be required to comply with the requests, orders, directives and requirements of AP to the extent such requests, orders, directives or requirements are (a) issued pursuant to Good Utility Practice, (b) not unduly discriminatory, and otherwise in accordance with applicable tariffs or Applicable Laws and Regulations, and (c) consistent with the requirements of this Agreement. In the event GENERATOR believes that a request, order or directive of AP exceeds these limitations, it shall nevertheless comply with the request, order or directive of AP in the event of Emergency Condition, to prevent Emergency Condition or during a condition in which equipment damage would be imminent. Such compliance shall not prejudice GENERATOR s right to pursue dispute resolution under Article 22. The Parties agree to cooperate in good faith to expedite the resolution of any Disputes arising under this Article 4.8. 4.9 To provide for the safe operation and maintenance of high voltage facilities, both Parties must be kept informed of all system conditions, including GENERATOR s plans for bringing its generator on or off line and AP s plans for system outages that could impact GENERATOR s ability to run its generators. Each Party shall coordinate inspections, planned outages and maintenance of their respective equipment, facilities and systems so as to minimize the impact on the availability, reliability and security of both Parties systems and operations. AP shall coordinate such maintenance interruptions with GENERATOR and shall provide GENERATOR with as much advance notice as possible but in no event shall the notice be less than three (3) business days except when AP determines an Emergency Condition exists or may exist that requires quicker action to correct. Neither Party shall be liable for lost income, lost opportunity costs or any other costs that the other Party incurs due to planned or unplanned outages on the Transmission System, AP s Interconnection Facilities, GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities, the Project or outside of AP s Control Area. AP normally limits maintenance interruptions to business hours on a business day, between 7:00 AM and 3:30 PM. In the event that GENERATOR desires the proposed maintenance interruption to occur during periods other than that specified above, AP reserves the right to charge GENERATOR the additional cost for work performed. For the purposes of coordinating AP s outage with GENERATOR outage, GENERATOR shall provide a preliminary schedule of planned outages (outage duration of one week or more) on an annual basis to AP in writing by July 15 for the ensuing calendar year. For each GENERATOR planned outage, GENERATOR will indicate the month, day, and year the planned outage is expected to begin and the month, day, and year the planned outage is expected to be completed. The capacity affected shall be indicated. If applicable, a preliminary request for maintenance power shall also be included. AP shall confirm the preliminary schedule by September 1. Any maintenance power requests will be confirmed within the time frame specified in the appropriate rate schedule. GENERATOR shall prepare and submit to AP by 11:00 am three working days prior to the day of scheduled planned outages of all types and duration at the Project except when GENERATOR determines an Emergency Condition exists or may exist that requires quicker action to correct. GENERATOR shall set forth in detail each such planned outage including the start and stop date and time. 4.10 GENERATOR shall ensure that the GENERATOR plant operator (or an alternative contact when the facility has been shut down) is available by telephone for monitoring and control of the facility twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week, fifty-two (52) weeks per year. Both Parties shall have a dedicated local telephone circuit. This telephone number shall be unlisted and limited to essential use for communications with entities such as the OC. In addition, GENERATOR shall have call waiting if available. For the purpose of coordinating AP operations, AP maintains a central dispatching office at its OC. AP shall have OC personnel available by telephone twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week, fifty-two (52) weeks per year. Address and phone numbers are specified in Article 24.10. 4.11 Personnel from AP or any designated Representative shall be provided access at any reasonable time and upon reasonable advance notice (orally or in writing) to any metering devices, power switching devices, or control devices or any other AP equipment installed on the GENERATOR property. Personnel from AP or any designated Representative may visit and inspect the Interconnection Facilities at any reasonable time and upon reasonable advance notice, orally or in writing. 4.12 The uniform assignment of names to interconnections, lines, substations, and substation equipment is necessary to provide a foundation for safe and efficient operation of the system and to maintain good records. The naming of GENERATOR equipment that interfaces with AP shall be provided to the OC prior to the initial operation and shall be shown on one-line diagrams and on the equipment itself. Equipment names must be installed on the equipment to provide clear and distinct identity to all lines and substation equipment. 4.13 Generation Control A.GENERATOR shall inform AP of its initial mode of operation no later than three months prior to Target Interconnection Completion Date. If GENERATOR elects manual mode for its initial mode of operation, GENERATOR may, with three months written notice and the necessary equipment, switch its mode of operation. It is GENERATOR s responsibility to protect the Project s generating units at all times. GENERATOR shall operate its generating units in one of the following generating control mode(s): 1. Automatic Dispatch Mode: If GENERATOR selects Automatic Dispatch Mode, the OC computers will be in control of GENERATOR s generating units for the purpose of automatic generation control, using dispatch price curves as directed by GENERATOR but subject to the further provisions of this Article 4.13 A. OC must set its automatic dispatch control limits for the units to values requested by GENERATOR and the rate of response for the units to the values which routinely derive from the application of subsection C below. The automatic dispatch control limits and rate of response shall also be included in the telemetered data from GENERATOR to the OC computer. In the event the OC computers are not available for Automatic Dispatch Mode, OC may direct GENERATOR to switch to Manual Dispatch Mode. If a problem occurs while in the Automatic Dispatch Mode, GENERATOR must take control of the units, such as switching to Manual Dispatch Mode, and notify OC operator of the status of the units and any problems with the units. GENERATOR may be in the Automatic Dispatch Mode only if GENERATOR is providing Ancillary Services to AP under a Ancillary Services agreement. 2. Manual Dispatch Mode: If GENERATOR selects Manual Dispatch Mode, the OC computers will not control GENERATOR s generating units. GENERATOR will be in full control of the Project output. 3. OC may also direct GENERATOR to switch to Manual Dispatch Mode from Automatic Dispatch Mode, or may direct GENERATOR to cease generating electricity for any of the following three (3) conditions: i)AP scheduled outages, which shall be scheduled in accordance with the requirements of this Agreement, including without limitation Article 4; or ii)Emergency Conditions; or, iii)Unacceptable electric characteristics such as but not limited to Project s units out of phase, voltage spikes. OC must record and must notify GENERATOR to record the condition under which orders to cease generating electricity or switch to Manual Dispatch Mode have been directed. In all cases, OC will attempt to minimize the duration of such conditions. Attempts will be made to inform GENERATOR as soon as reasonably possible of scheduled outages, system emergencies and if applicable LEER or MRD (if GENERATOR has elected to participate in LEER or MRD). In Manual Dispatch Mode, OC shall not request GENERATOR to operate below GENERATOR s Minimum Dispatch Output nor above GENERATOR s Maximum Output. B.GENERATOR shall maintain its speed governor droop as close as practicable to five percent (5%). C.If GENERATOR experiences a change in unit output, OC must be notified immediately of the amount of, and reason for the change, the expected duration of and the time at which all such changes became effective. GENERATOR shall notify OC operator by telephone as soon as practicable when there is a change in status on its units (either coming on or coming off line). At such time, GENERATOR shall provide AP with the ramp rate of the units. AP shall determine if the ramp rate needs to be modified. GENERATOR shall comply with such ramp rate modification subject to the Design Limits. 4.14 Voltage Responsibility (a) The Project shall not adversely impact the voltage profile at the Interconnection Point. GENERATOR shall be tested for reactive capability range at the Interconnection Point during the start up and testing procedures pursuant to Article 7. This test shall also demonstrate GENERATOR s ability to maintain the historical pre-project voltage within the tested reactive capability range. The historical pre-project voltage schedule is provided in Exhibit I. In the event GENERATOR fails such test, AP may require at GENERATOR s expense installation of a dynamic reactive source to meet such requirements. (b) OC shall be responsible for monitoring overall system conditions and GENERATOR shall take such voltage corrective action, as OC shall require. OC shall provide a voltage schedule as measured at the Interconnection Point. At all times during which GENERATOR is operating its units, GENERATOR shall continuously operate its generators so as to follow this voltage schedule within +/- 0.5%. OC shall notify GENERATOR immediately by telephone if GENERATOR exceeds the +/- 0.5% voltage accuracy range. GENERATOR shall maintain such voltage schedule provided the voltage schedule can be maintained within the GENERATOR reactive capabilities as tested pursuant to Article 4.14 (a). In the event the GENERATOR does not meet the voltage schedule provided by OC, provided such schedule could be maintained within the reactive capabilities as tested pursuant to Article 4.14 (a), GENERATOR shall be subject to one of the following penalties: (i) Penalty = MVAR deviation from tested reactive capability as tested in Article 4.14(a)* $/MVARH or $/MVARH shall be based on a carrying charge for a dynamic reactive source over the estimated time in which the Project would be on line over a ten year period. (v)AP may require at GENERATOR s expense, the installation of a dynamic reactive source to meet the reactive capabilities of the Project as initially tested in Article 4.14(a). The GENERATOR shall only be responsible for providing reactive capability equal to the reactive capabilities as tested in Article 4.14(a). AP is solely responsible for all costs associated with the installation of additional reactive capabilities in excess of the GENERATOR s tested reactive capabilities. (c) GENERATOR shall provide AP Design Limits as specified in Article 1.11. Design Limits shall be reviewed and approved by AP. Any changes in the generator capability curves and controls that may change the units dynamic model from those set forth in the Design Limits shall be mutually agreed to in writing by GENERATOR and AP. GENERATOR agrees to cooperate with AP in setting main transformer taps to optimize GENERATOR s ability to operate within the voltage schedule provided by AP. (d) The GENERATOR automatic voltage regulation must be in service when the Project is on line, except when GENERATOR takes corrective action required by OC. In the event GENERATOR's voltage regulation is Out of Service or operating improperly, GENERATOR shall immediately notify OC by telephone. This condition may cause interconnection problems, which would require GENERATOR to be off line until the problem is corrected. (e) Not withstanding the penalties in 4.14 (b), GENERATOR shall be responsible for any penalties, damages, or any other costs incurred by AP that are directly and proportionally due to GENERATOR s failure to meet the obligations set forth in this Article 4.14; provided, however, that any penalties accessed pursuant to this Article 4.14 (e) shall be reduced by amounts previously paid by GENERATOR pursuant to Article 4.14(b)(i) in connection with the occurrence of the events giving rise to the imposition of penalties pursuant to this Article 4.14 (e). 4.15 Operation of GENERATOR s _____kV Breaker In the event AP determines the operation (opening or closing) of GENERATOR s ___ kV breaker will cause an Emergency Condition on Transmission System, GENERATOR shall not operate its breaker until AP authorizes such operation. 4.16 Switching Scope and Limitations Switching scope and limitations is specified in Exhibit K. 4.17 Hourly Output GENERATOR shall electronically transmit to OC the hourly output of the GENERATOR unit(s). GENERATOR shall provide the hourly readings by telephone in the event the normal electronic communication path is unavailable. OC will acquire the 24-hour totals from AP s meters located at the Interconnection Point. If Project is manned, AP may also check and confirm the 24-hour totals with the GENERATOR by telephone each night after the midnight readings are complete. 4.18 Operating Log Both Parties shall maintain operating log(s) with records of hourly real power production, all changes in equipment operating status, planned and unplanned outages, and any unusual conditions found during inspections. The date and time of each logged occurrence will be clearly identified with each logged entry. The time will be reported in 24-hour military format using, as appropriate, Eastern Prevailing Time. Each Party shall provide the other Party such information within thirty (30) days of the other Party s request. Both Parties operating logs must be retained at least 7 years before the Parties may discard them. 4.19 Notifications and Reporting of Emergency Conditions Each Party shall provide prompt verbal notice to the other Party of any Emergency Condition which may be reasonably anticipated to affect the other Party's equipment, facilities or operations, provided that, to the extent applicable, notices regarding constraints, curtailments or interruptions shall be provided consistent with FERC Order Nos. 889, 889 A and any successor thereto. Such verbal notification shall be followed by written notification, describing the nature and extent of the condition, the impact on operations and all corrective action, within forty eight (48) hours of the first mentioned Party's knowledge of such Emergency Condition. Either Party may take reasonable and necessary action, both on its own and the other Party's system, equipment, and facilities, to prevent, avoid or mitigate injury, danger, damage or loss to its own equipment and facilities, or to expedite restoration of service; provided, however, that the Party taking such action shall give the other Party prior notice if at all possible before taking any action on the other Party's system, equipment or facilities. In the event of an Emergency Condition, each Party shall provide the other Party with such information, documents, and data necessary for operation of the Project and the Transmission System including, without limitation, such information which is to be supplied by either Party. ARTICLE 5 Metering 5.1 AP shall at GENERATOR s expense, in accordance with Good Utility Practice, install, own, operate, test, and maintain revenue meters and related equipment for the Interconnection Point that measure electric power flows between the Project and AP at the Interconnection Point. GENERATOR may install parallel meters to those installed by AP that meet the requirements of this Article 5. AP s meters will be used to measure power flows under this Agreement unless AP s meters are found to be inaccurate or defective in which case GENERATOR s meters will be used if such equipment has been tested in accordance with the requirements of this Article 5 and shown to be metering accurately. The information provided by the metering facilities shall meet the reasonable needs and approvals of both Parties, consistent with Good Utility Practice. In the event there is a discrepancy with respect to installation and maintenance costs associated with metering between this Agreement and any other contract or tariff, this Agreement shall prevail. 5.2 (a) AP shall inspect and test or cause to be inspected and tested all AP s metering devices upon the installation thereof, at GENERATOR s expense. Upon request of GENERATOR, AP shall, and from time to time AP may, inspect or test or cause to be inspected or tested any AP metering device at any other reasonable time and shall permit or cause to be permitted an authorized representative of GENERATOR to be present at any such inspection or test. The cost and expense of any such inspection or test shall be paid by GENERATOR. If a metering device is found to be defective or inaccurate, it shall be adjusted, calibrated, repaired or replaced by AP at GENERATOR s expense unless such defect or inaccuracy is due to faulty installation or operation and maintenance by AP. (b) Any inaccuracy disclosed by tests specified in Article 5.2 shall be promptly corrected by AP. If in any test a meter is found to be inaccurate by more than two percent, fast or slow, an adjustment shall be made in settlements hereunder to compensate for such inaccuracy over a period not to exceed two months, as the inaccuracy is determined to have existed. If at any time a meter should fail to register or its registration should be so erratic as to be meaningless, the estimated correct registration for billing purposes shall be based upon records of check meters, if available, or otherwise upon the best obtainable data. If the GENERATOR has installed meters and, upon testing by AP, the GENERATOR s meters are found to be registering accurately, the reading of the Generator s meters shall be used when testing under Article 5.2 discloses any inaccuracy of two percent or greater in AP s meters. 5.3 AP s Metering and related equipment shall be as follows: (a) The Project shall have interconnection metering facilities installed to provide direct readings of the Project s bi directional net real and reactive power and energy output. Meters shall have metered interval processing (MIP) capability. The metering instrument transformers used to measure the Project's net output shall be installed on or compensated to the Interconnection Point. Such metering shall be owned, operated and maintained by AP at GENERATOR s expense and shall be located within AP s fenced enclosure of AP s Interconnection Facilities. (b)All plant auxiliary power transformers and lines directly connected to AP's ___ kV transmission system shall have metering facilities installed to provide bi directional real and reactive power and energy flow. Metering instrument transformers shall be connected to or compensated to the Interconnection Point, unless otherwise agreed to by the Parties. All plant auxiliary power transformers and lines directly connected to AP s distribution system shall have metering facilities installed to provide real and reactive power and energy flow. Metering instrument transformers shall be connected to or compensated to the primary voltage side of the distribution step down transformer, unless otherwise agreed to by the Parties. AP shall own and maintain, at GENERATOR s expense, such metering devices. (c)GENERATOR shall supply a voice-grade phone circuit dedicated to remote interrogation of the metering to AP s Operations Center. (d)All metering instrument transformers installed must be strictly in accordance with the latest version of IEEE Standard C57.13 and, if applicable, ANSI Standard C93. 1. AP requires a 0.3 percent accuracy or better on all instrument transformers and meters. (e)The metering devices shall be sealed. AP shall give or cause to be given to GENERATOR access to the metering devices at any reasonable time upon reasonable notice. The seals shall be broken by AP only when the metering devices are to be inspected, tested or adjusted pursuant to the this Agreement, provided, however, that GENERATOR shall receive reasonable prior notice thereof and shall have the right to be present. 5.4 (a) AP shall, at GENERATOR s expense, maintain real-time communications equipment, that in any form or configuration shall be known as a Remote Terminal Unit ( RTU ) of which there may be more than one at the Project to send generation data to and receive data from AP Operations Center s Energy Management System computer, as reasonably required by AP. GENERATOR shall at its expense, install such equipment. Such data shall include, but not be limited to, normal operations, control of circuit breakers, status and alarms of equipment and watts, vars, amperes, and voltage. (b) Remote data acquisition of the Project s meters shall be performed at GENERATOR s expense by polling of an RTU by Operations Center's Energy Management System computer at a scan rate to be reasonably determined by AP. The data collected shall include the bi directional instantaneous values of megawatts and megavars and bi directional accumulated megawatt hours and megavar hours for each generating unit of the Project, and such other data as may be specified by AP. AP may adopt such measures as are necessary for security of the metering facilities and data. AP will upon GENERATOR s request and expense, provide any and all such data to GENERATOR for any period of time over which AP may retain such data. (c) If pursuant to Article 4.13, GENERATOR elects to operate its generating units in Automatic Dispatch Mode, then in order for GENERATOR to provide automatic dispatch mode specified in Article 4 from AP s Operations Center s Energy Management System computer, GENERATOR shall provide at its expense the following points for each unit: Input-Analog Points High Limit Low Limit Rate of Response Net MVAR at Interconnection Point out Net MW at Interconnection Point out Output-Analog Point Unit MW Desired Set point Input-Status Points Unit Online/Offline Unit On/Off AGC Control Unit at Max Unit at Min Unit Control Blocking In the event GENERATOR elects to run in the manual dispatch mode specified in Article 4, GENERATOR shall provide at its expense the following points for each unit: Input-Analog Points Rate of Response Net MVAR at Interconnection Point out Net MW at Interconnection Point out Input-Status Points Unit Online/Offline Unit at Max Unit at Min (d) GENERATOR shall install at its expense fiber optic or other mutually agreed upon communication and termination equipment as required by AP for the interconnection of the Project. AP has install and will maintain at its expense an Energy Management System having data acquisition and control capability for AP to perform its automatic or manual dispatch role. Any enhancement to the AP Energy Management System to accommodate GENERATOR will be at GENERATOR s expense. ARTICLE 6 Relaying 6.1 AP shall have the right, using Good Utility Practice, to review and approve all new protective relaying logic equipment, including equipment settings, drawings, and functionality associated with the Interconnection Point, and to review all protective relaying logic equipment, including equipment settings, drawings, and functionality for the Project. 6.2 As AP system protection requirements change and as system protection technology advances, AP will upgrade, at GENERATOR s expense, AP s protection systems in accordance with Good Utility Practice. If these upgrades affect the serviceability and acceptability of the protective relaying systems on the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities, GENERATOR agrees to upgrade, at its expense, its protective relaying systems to bring them into compatibility with and to the same technological standards as those installed by AP. 6.3 GENERATOR shall provide the necessary space to install or expand relay panels for substation system protection as reasonably requested by AP in the initial design phase of the Project. ARTICLE 7 Initial Construction and Testing of Interconnection Facilities 7.1 Review, Approval and Inspection of GENERATOR s Facilities (a) The design and construction of GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities (including the design and specifications for the protective equipment and all modifications to the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities, and all electrical drawings and one-line diagrams relating thereto) shall be subject to the review and approval of AP. As soon as practical, GENERATOR shall provide AP with all designs, specifications and drawings as they relate to the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities (collectively, the "Drawings"). The Drawings will be of good engineering quality and shall include but not be limited to the following: (i) One line diagram showing the connections between the Project and the Transmission System; (ii) Three-line diagrams showing current and potential circuits for protective relays; (vi)Relay tripping and control schematic diagram; and (iv) Instruction books for system protection elements. (b) AP shall provide GENERATOR with written notice of its approval of such Drawings or a detailed description of any objections thereto with specific actions that GENERATOR may take to satisfy AP s objections, which approval shall not unreasonably be withheld. GENERATOR shall take appropriate action to correct any such objections and resubmit the Drawings for AP s review in accordance with the first sentence of this Article 7.1(b). GENERATOR shall construct the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities in accordance with the Drawings provided to and approved by AP. (c) Before the Project is interconnected with the AP System, GENERATOR shall provide AP with reasonable notice and opportunity to inspect and test GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities. This inspection and testing may include, but need not be limited to: (i) the acceptance testing of all protective equipment according to AP minimum requirements; (ii) the placement of in-service relay taps according to settings; (iii) the operability of the protective equipment; and (iv) the phasing and synchronizing checks of all related equipment. (d) GENERATOR shall provide AP with written notice when it believes that the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities and the Project are completed. AP shall inspect the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities and AP shall provide written approval or notice of defects or failure to comply with this Agreement. GENERATOR shall take appropriate actions to correct any such defects or failure and shall obtain AP s inspection and approval of the corrections, which approval shall not unreasonably be withheld. (e) Final approval by AP of the Drawings and GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities is required before parallel operation may begin. AP shall have the right to reasonable notice of, and to be present for, the initial paralleling. Any AP approval under this Article 7, which shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed, shall not be valid unless in writing. (f) AP s approvals under this Article 7.1 and any other approval or inspection by AP hereunder with respect to the Project or GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities are limited to the purpose of ensuring the safety, reliability, security, protection and control of the Transmission System and shall not be construed as confirming or endorsing the Drawings or the design or any other aspect of any protective equipment, GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities or the Project, or as a warranty or guarantee of any type, including as to safety, durability or reliability thereof. AP s review or approval of, or comments on, any document provided by GENERATOR shall not relieve GENERATOR of its responsibility for the correctness or adequacy of the document or work to be performed. Each Party shall be responsible for drawing updates and corrections to their respective drawings and shall provide copies to the other Party as soon as possible thereafter. 7.2 Start-up and Testing Program (a) At the request of a Party, the other Party shall submit a report to the requesting Party regarding progress of the installation of such other Party's Interconnection Facilities and other facilities to be constructed by such Party in connection therewith. Both Parties acknowledge the importance of ongoing communication and discussion with respect to the matters covered by this Agreement, and both Parties will coordinate their respective activities and meet or otherwise communicate on a regular basis to anticipate and resolve problems related to the respective obligations of GENERATOR and AP in connection with the design, installation and testing of the Interconnection Facilities. (b) AP and GENERATOR shall cooperate with each other and coordinate completion of their respective work under this Agreement to support the interface and testing of the Interconnection Facilities and the interconnection of the Project with the Transmission System by the Targeted Interconnection Completion Date. Prior to execution of this Agreement, the Parties shall develop a start-up and testing program for the Interconnection Facilities to demonstrate the compliance of the GENERATOR s Interconnection Facilities and the AP s Interconnection Facilities with the requirements of this Agreement. The start-up and testing program shall include reactive capability testing of the Project. Such start-up and testing programs shall be incorporated into this Agreement as Exhibit F. ARTICLE 8 New Construction and Modifications 8.1 GENERATOR shall not make modifications to, or perform new construction of, facilities, or access thereto, including but not limited to rights of way, fences, and gates except for routine maintenance without (a) prior written notification and consent by AP as set forth in this Article 8, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed, and (b) providing AP with sufficient information regarding the work prior to commencement to enable AP to evaluate the impact of the proposed work on its operations. The information provided must be of sufficient detail to satisfy AP review of operational requirements. In implementing any AP approved modifications, GENERATOR shall use reasonable efforts to minimize any adverse impact on AP. In the event AP intends to make modifications to the electrical system which will impose an outage on the Project, AP shall provide GENERATOR with sufficient information regarding the work prior to commencement to enable GENERATOR to evaluate the impact of the proposed work on its operations. Any information provided hereunder must be of sufficient detail to satisfy GENERATOR review of operational requirements. In implementing any such modifications, AP shall use Due Diligence efforts to minimize any adverse impact on GENERATOR. 8.2 For new generation installations or modifications by GENERATOR at the Project site, GENERATOR shall furnish, install and maintain equipment at the Project necessary to establish and maintain synchronism with AP s Transmission System consistent with Applicable Law and Regulations and Good Utility Practice. If said modifications involve a proposed new or materially changed Interconnection Point, a change in the generating capacity of the Project, or the addition of a new generating unit(s), GENERATOR shall submit an application in accordance with AP's procedures applicable to new interconnections to the Transmission System. 8.3 Within thirty (30) days following completion of any modification or construction subject to this Article 8, GENERATOR shall provide "as built" drawings, plans and related technical data to AP. Approval or review of any document referenced herein shall not relieve GENERATOR of its responsibility for the design or construction of any proposed facility, nor shall it subject AP to any liability. 8.4 Each Party shall, at its own expense, have the right to inspect or observe all maintenance activities, equipment tests, installation work, construction work and modification work to the facilities of the other Party that could have a material effect upon the facilities or operations of the first Party. 8.5 Unless otherwise required by Applicable Laws and Regulations, OATT, Good Utility Practice, or this Agreement, neither Party shall be required at any time to upgrade or otherwise modify the their respective facilities or equipment. 8.6 Neither Party shall make changes to the site topography or accesses, including but not limited to grading or drainage, that could reasonably be expected to have a material adverse effect upon the other Party's facilities or common use drainage or pollution controls systems without the prior written consent of the other Party, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed. ARTICLE 9 Notifications and Reporting 9.1 Each Party shall promptly provide the other Party with all relevant information, documents, or data regarding the Project and the Transmission System that would be expected to affect the Transmission System or the Project, and which is reasonably requested by NERC, ECAR, or any Governmental Authority. Each Party will protect to the extent possible given the rules and regulations of the noted requestors the confidentiality of the other Party s data as envisioned in Article 23. 9.2 Each Party agrees to immediately notify the other Party, verbally and then in writing, of any labor dispute or anticipated labor dispute of which its management has actual knowledge that might reasonably be expected to affect the operations of the other Party with respect to this Agreement ARTICLE 10 Environmental Compliance and Procedures 10.1 Each Party shall meet all necessary environmental requirements applicable to its facilities. GENERATOR at its own expense shall apply for all such licenses or permits needed for such compliance. 10.2 Each Party shall verbally notify the other Party, immediately upon discovery of any hazardous substance on its property or facilities, which may migrate to, or adversely impact the property, facilities or operations of, the other Party. The Party obligated to provide such notification is the Notifying Party . The Notifying Party shall follow its verbal notification with written notification within twenty four (24) hours. The Notifying Party shall be responsible for performing any remediation or abatement activity and submitting all notification, reports or filings required by Environmental Laws. The Notifying Party shall also assume all costs associated with performing any remediation or abatement activity and submitting notification, reports or filings required by Environmental Laws. Advance written notification of all remediation and abatement activity (except in emergency situations, in which verbal, followed by written notification, shall be provided as soon as practicable, but no later than five business days) shall be provided by the Notifying Party to the other Party. Except in emergency situations, such remediation or abatement activity shall be performed only with the consent of the Party owning the affected property or facilities. The Parties agree to coordinate, to the extent necessary, the preparation of site plans, reports or filings required by law or regulation, including but not limited to Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) and Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plans (SWPPP) required by any regulatory agency of competent jurisdiction. 10.3 Should either Party discover any hazardous substance on the other Party s property or facilities, which may migrate to, or adversely impact either Party s property, facilities or operations, it shall notify the other Party as set forth in Section 10.2 hereof. The provisions of Section 10.2 hereof shall apply in such event, except that all responsibility for and all costs associated with remediation or abatement activity and submitting notification, reports or filings required by Environmental Laws shall be borne by the Party upon whose property or facilities the hazardous substance is discovered, unless such hazardous substances are determined to have originated from the other Party s property. ARTICLE 11 Billings and Payment 11.1 Any invoices for reimbursable services provided to the other Party under this Agreement during the preceding month shall be prepared within a reasonable time after the first day of each month. Each invoice shall delineate the month in which the services were provided and shall be accompanied by such supporting documentation as reasonably necessary to substantiate the invoiced amount. The invoice shall be paid within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the invoice. All payments shall be made in immediately available funds payable to the other Party, or by wire transfer to a bank named by the Party being paid, provided that payments expressly required by this Agreement to be mailed shall be mailed in accordance with Article 24. 11.2 The rate of interest on any amount not paid when due shall be equal to the Interest Rate in effect at the time such amount became due. Interest on delinquent amounts shall be calculated from the due date of the bill to the date of payment. When payments are made by mail, bills shall be considered as having been paid on the date of receipt by the other Party. Nothing contained in this Article is intended to limit either Party's remedies under Article 18 of this Agreement. 11.3 Payment of an invoice shall not relieve the paying Party from any responsibilities or obligations it has under this Agreement, nor shall such payment constitute a waiver of any claims arising hereunder. 11.4If all or part of any bill is disputed by a Party, that Party shall promptly pay the amount that is not disputed and provide the other Party a reasonably detailed written explanation of the basis for the Dispute pursuant to Article 22. Upon resolution of the Dispute, the prevailing Party shall be entitled to receive the disputed amount, as finally determined to be payable, along with interest accrued at the Interest Rate through the date on which payment is made, within ten (10) business days of such resolution. 11.5For a period of two (2) years following a calendar year, during normal business hours, GENERATOR and AP shall have the right to audit each other's accounts and records pertaining to transactions under this Agreement that occurred during such calendar year at the offices where such accounts and records are maintained; provided that the audit shall be limited to those portions of such accounts and records that reasonably relate to the services provided to the other Party under this Agreement for said calendar year. The Party being audited shall be entitled to review the audit report and any supporting materials. To the extent that audited information includes Confidential Information, the auditing Party shall keep all such information confidential pursuant to Article 23 hereof. 11.6 To further secure the full and faithful performance of all obligations of GENERATOR hereunder, (including, without limitation to Article 15.1) AP shall have the right from to time to time (and as often as AP may deem necessary) to require GENERATOR to provide and maintain in effect during the term of this Agreement a performance/payment bond, an unconditional irrevocable and evergreen letter of credit or cash collateral as security to meet GENERATOR s responsibilities and obligations under this Agreement. In connection with providing such collateral (and in addition to GENERATOR hereby granting a security interest to AP in and to such collateral), AP shall have the right to require GENERATOR to execute and deliver a security agreement pledging such collateral to AP, which security agreement shall be in form and substance satisfactory to AP, in AP s sole discretion. The obligations of GENERATOR secured by such collateral shall include, without limitation, payments required in connection with the construction of the Interconnection Facilities, as well as the on-going obligations of GENERATOR in connection with this Agreement. Such collateral shall be satisfactory to AP, in its sole discretion, as to both form and substance. Should such collateral be in the form of a bond or letter of credit, AP shall have the right to approve the financial strength of the issuer or surety. GENERATOR may also provide an alternative form of security proposed by GENERATOR acceptable to AP, in AP s sole discretion and consistent with good commercial practices protecting AP against the risk of non-payment or non-performance. Upon a default by GENERATOR hereunder that remains uncured beyond the express cure period provided in this Agreement (and in addition to all remedies available to AP hereunder), AP shall have the right to utilize and realize upon such collateral for payment (in whole or in part) of sums owed to AP. Should the collateral be reduced because AP has utilized or realized upon such collateral, AP shall have the right to require GENERATOR to restore or increase such collateral upon demand, and failure to so restore or increase the collateral upon demand shall be deemed a material default under this Agreement. ARTICLE 12 Applicable Regulations and Interpretation 12.1 Each Party's performance under this Agreement is subject to the condition that all requisite governmental and regulatory acceptances for such performance are obtained. Each Party shall exercise Due Diligence and shall act in good faith to secure all appropriate acceptances. If this Agreement is filed as an executed agreement and it is not accepted without modification by the FERC, the Parties agree to renegotiate in good faith an amendment or amendments to this Agreement so as to preserve the original bargain of the Parties to the extent consistent with the FERC mandated modifications to the Agreement. If either Party seeks rehearing or appeals the FERC s decision with regard to the Agreement, absent the entering of a stay of the FERC s order, while such rehearing request or appeal is pending the Parties shall perform their obligations under this Agreement pursuant to the modifications mandated by the FERC. If a stay of the FERC s order is entered, each Party shall perform its obligations under this Agreement as initially filed pending resolution of the appeal. 12.2 AP shall file this Agreement with the FERC. Subject to the provisions of this Section 12.2, GENERATOR agrees to support such filing. If this Agreement is filed as an unexecuted agreement with the FERC, the Parties shall have no duty to support the Agreement with respect to issues which, after good faith negotiation, they have failed to resolve. The Parties shall, however, support all other portions of the Agreement and shall endeavor, to the extent reasonably possible, to narrow the issues presented to the FERC for resolution. GENERATOR shall reimburse AP for the filing costs and other reasonably incurred costs associated with the initial filing of this Agreement with the FERC whether in executed or unexecuted form. Each Party shall be responsible for its own costs associated with any request for rehearing, reconsideration or appeal of the FERC s order issued in connection with the filing of this Agreement. If this Agreement is filed as an unexecuted agreement, each Party shall be responsible for its own costs associated with advocating its position with respect to unresolved issues presented to the FERC for resolution. 12.3 This Agreement is made subject to state or federal laws, regulations, or orders properly issued by state or federal bodies having jurisdiction. This Agreement shall be interpreted pursuant to the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the Federal Power Act, and the regulations of any regulatory agency or agencies having jurisdiction over the particular matter. ARTICLE 13 Force Majeure 13.1 Neither Party shall be considered in default under this Agreement or responsible to the other Party whether in tort, strict liability, contract or other legal theory for damages of any description for any interruption or failure of service or deficiency in the quality or quantity of service or any other failure to perform any of its obligations hereunder to the extent such failure occurs without fault or negligence on the part of that Party and is caused by factors beyond that Party's reasonable control, which by the exercise of Due Diligence in accordance with Good Utility Practice, that Party is unable to prevent, avoid, mitigate or overcome, including without limitation storm, flood, fire, lightning, earthquake, explosion, civil disturbance, labor dispute, act of God or the public enemy, action or inaction of a court or public authority or any other cause of similar nature beyond the reasonable control of that Party (any such event is a "Force Majeure"). Economic hardship of either Party shall not constitute Force Majeure under this Agreement. Nor shall anything contained in this paragraph or elsewhere in this Agreement excuse GENERATOR or AP from strict compliance with the obligation of the Parties to comply with the terms of Article 11 of this Agreement relating to timely payments. 13.2 Each Party shall have the obligation to operate in accordance with Good Utility Practice at all times and to use Due Diligence to overcome and remove any cause of failure to perform. 13.3 If a Party relies on the occurrence of an event or condition described above as a basis for being excused from performance of its obligation under this Agreement, then the Party relying on the event or condition shall: (i) provide prompt written notice of such Force Majeure event to the other Party, giving an estimate of its expected duration and the probable impact on the performance of its obligations hereunder; (ii) exercise all reasonable efforts to continue to perform its obligations under this Agreement; (iii) expeditiously take action to correct or cure the event or condition excusing performance; provided, however, that settlement of strikes or other labor disputes will be completely within the sole discretion of the Party affected by such strike or labor dispute; (iv) exercise all reasonable efforts to mitigate or limit damages to the other Party; and (v) provide prompt notice to the other Party of the cessation of the event or condition giving rise to its excuse from performance. All performance obligations hereunder shall be extended by a period equal to the period of inability to perform caused by such Force Majeure event. 13.4 If a Party responding to a Force Majeure event has the ability to obtain, for additional expenditures, expedited material deliveries or labor production which would allow a response to the event in a manner that is above and beyond Good Utility Practice, such a response could shorten the duration of the event, and a shorter duration of the event could lessen the economic hardship of the other Party, the Party responding to the event may, at its discretion, present the other Party with the option of funding the expenditures for expediting material deliveries or labor production in an effort to reduce the duration of the event and economic hardship. Each such opportunity will be negotiated on a case by case basis by the Parties. ARTICLE 14 Liability 14.1 Except to the extent of the other Party s negligence or willful misconduct of its employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors, Representatives or invitees, each Party shall indemnify the other Party pursuant to Article 15 for all physical damage to or destruction of, or any personal injury or death associated with, the property, equipment and/or facilities owned by it and its Affiliates, resulting from any act or failure to act under this Agreement; but in any such case AP and GENERATOR will exercise Due Diligence to remove the cause of any disability at the earliest practicable time. 14.2 To the fullest extent permitted by law and notwithstanding other provisions of this Agreement, in no event shall AP, its Affiliates, or any of their respective officers, directors, employees, agents, successors or assigns be liable to GENERATOR, whether in contract, warranty, tort, negligence, strict liability, or otherwise, for special, indirect, incidental, multiple, consequential (including, without limitation, replacement power costs, lost profits or revenues, and lost business opportunities), or punitive damages, related to or resulting from any act or failure to act under this Agreement or any activity associated with or arising out of this Agreement. 14.3 To the fullest extent permitted by law and notwithstanding other provisions of this Agreement, in no event shall GENERATOR, its Affiliates, or any of its respective officers, directors, employees, agents, successors or assigns be liable to AP, whether in contract, warranty, tort, negligence, strict liability, or otherwise, for special, indirect, incidental, multiple, consequential (including, without limitation, replacement power costs, lost profits or revenues, and lost business opportunities), or punitive damages, related to or resulting from any act or failure to act under this Agreement or any activity associated with or arising out of this Agreement. 14.4 The provisions of this Article 14 shall survive termination, cancellation, suspension, completion or expiration of this Agreement. ARTICLE 15 Indemnification 15.1 GENERATOR's Indemnification. Subject to the provisions of Articles 14.1, 14.2, and 14.3, GENERATOR shall indemnify, hold harmless and defend AP, its parent, its Affiliates, and its and their officers, directors, employees, shareholders, agents, contractors, subcontractors, invitees and successors, from and against any and all claims, demands, suits, obligations, payments, liabilities, costs, losses, judgments, damages and expenses (including the reasonable costs and expenses of any and all actions, suits, proceedings, assessments, judgments, settlements, and compromises relating thereto, reasonable attorneys' and expert fees and reasonable disbursements in connection therewith) associated with damage to property, injury to or death of any person, including AP's employees and their Affiliates' employees, or any third parties, to the extent caused by any act or omission, negligent or otherwise, by GENERATOR or its officers, directors, employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors and invitees arising out of or connected with GENERATOR's performance or breach of this Agreement, or the exercise by GENERATOR of its rights hereunder. In furtherance of the foregoing indemnification and not by way of limitation thereof, GENERATOR hereby waives any defense it otherwise might have under applicable workers compensation laws. 15.2 AP's Indemnification. Subject to the provisions of Articles 14.1, 14.2 and 14.3, AP shall indemnify, hold harmless and defend GENERATOR, its parent, Affiliates, and its their officers, directors, employees, shareholders, agents, contractors, subcontractors, invitees and successors, from and against any and all claims, demands, suits, obligations, payments, liabilities, costs, losses, judgments, damages and expenses (including the reasonable costs and expenses of any and all actions, suits, proceedings, assessments, judgments, settlements, and compromises relating thereto reasonable attorneys' and expert fees and reasonable disbursements in connection therewith) associated with damage to property, injury to or death of any person, including GENERATOR's employees, AP's employees and their Affiliates' employees, or any third parties, to the extent caused by any act or omission, negligent or otherwise, by AP or its officers, directors, employees, agents, contractors, subcontractors and invitees arising out of or connected with AP's performance or breach of this Agreement, or the exercise by AP of its rights hereunder. In furtherance of the foregoing indemnification and not by way of limitation thereof, AP hereby waives any defense it otherwise might have under applicable workers' compensation laws. 15.3 Indemnification Procedures. Any Party seeking indemnification under this Agreement shall give the other Party notice of such claim promptly. Such notice shall describe the claim in reasonable detail, and shall indicate the amount (estimated if necessary) of the claim that has been, or may be sustained by, said Party. Neither Party may settle or compromise any claim for which indemnification is sought under this Agreement without the prior consent of the other Party; provided, however, said consent shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. ARTICLE 16 Insurance 16.1 GENERATOR agrees to maintain at its own cost and expense, fire, liability, worker's compensation, and other forms of insurance, or equivalent self-insurance acceptable to AP, relating to its property and facilities in the manner, and amounts, and for the duration set forth in Exhibit 2 to this Agreement, as both Parties may, from time to time, agree to amend. AP may require GENERATOR to maintain coverage for five years on all policies written on a "claims made" basis. 16.2 Every contract of insurance providing the coverage required in Exhibit B shall include provisions or endorsements (i) stating that such insurance is primary insurance with respect to the interest of AP and that any insurance maintained by AP is excess and not contributory insurance required hereunder, and (ii) providing that no reduction, cancellation or expiration of the policy shall be effective until thirty (30) days from the date written notice thereof is actually received by AP. Upon GENERATOR's receipt of any notice of reduction, cancellation or expiration, GENERATOR shall immediately provide written notice thereof to AP. 16.3 AP shall be named as additional insured on the general liability insurance policies of the GENERATOR set forth in Exhibit B as their interests may appear with respect to this Agreement. 16.4 At least fifteen days prior to the Targeted Interconnection Completion Date, GENERATOR shall provide to AP, and shall continue to provide to AP at least fifteen (15) days prior to each anniversary of the Target Interconnection Completion Date thereafter, properly executed and current certificates of insurance with respect to all insurance policies required to be maintained by GENERATOR under this Agreement. Certificates of insurance shall provide the following information: (i)Name of insurance company, policy number and expiration date. (ii) The coverage required and the limits on each, including the amount of deductibles or self insured retention, which shall be for the account of the Party maintaining such policy. (iii) A statement indicating that AP shall receive at least thirty (30) days prior written notice of cancellation or expiration of a policy, or reduction of liability limits with respect to a policy, and (iv) A statement indicating that the AP and its Affiliates have been named as additional insured. 16.5 At AP's request, in addition to the foregoing certifications, GENERATOR shall deliver to AP a copy of each insurance policy, certified as a true copy by an authorized representative of the issuing insurance company. 16.6 AP shall have the right to inspect the original policies of insurance applicable to this Agreement at GENERATOR's place of business during regular business hours. ARTICLE 17 Several Obligations Except where specifically stated in this Agreement to be otherwise, the duties, obligations and liabilities of the Parties are intended to be several and not joint or collective. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall ever be construed to create an association, trust, partnership, or joint venture or to impose a trust or partnership duty, obligation or liability or agency relationship on or with regard to either Party. Each Party shall be individually and severally liable for its own obligations under this Agreement. ARTICLE 18 Remedies . 18.1In the event that either Party (the "Delinquent Party") fails to make full payment of the undisputed portion of any invoice rendered under this Agreement on or before the due date, the other Party (the "Non Delinquent Party") shall give the Delinquent Party notice in writing of such delinquency, and the Delinquent Party will have thirty (30) business days from the date of its receipt of such written notice to cure such delinquency. In the event the Delinquent Party fails to make full payment of the delinquent amount (including interest accrued at the Interest Rate) within such 30 calendar day period, the Delinquent Party will be in default. 18.2If either Party fails to fulfill obligations under this Agreement (in such event, a "Defaulting Party ), following thirty (30) calendar days prior written notice (which specifies the nature of such failure in reasonable detail) to the Defaulting Party (except in cases of emergencies in which case only such notice as shall be reasonably practicable in the circumstances), the Defaulting Party shall be deemed in default, and the Non Defaulting Party may immediately terminate this Agreement or may agree with the Defaulting Party to extend the termination date, and provided further that without prejudice to its right to recover such damages as may be appropriate and such termination shall be without prejudice to any other legal or equitable remedies available to AP or GENERATOR, provided that after AP files this Agreement with FERC, AP shall file notice to FERC to terminate service under this Agreement or for such other sanctions as may be appropriate, and such filing shall be without prejudice to any other legal or equitable remedies available to AP. 18.3 AP may disconnect the Project from Transmission System if the GENERATOR fails to meet its obligations set forth in this Agreement. Except as described in Article 4.3 prior to such disconnection AP shall provide written notice to GENERATOR detailing GENERATOR s failure to adhere to such requirements and provide GENERATOR thirty (30) calendar days to correct such deficiency. AP shall not disconnect the Project if GENERATOR corrects the deficiencies described in the written notice within thirty (30) calendar days or a mutually agreed upon period. AP reserves the right to terminate this Agreement if AP disconnects the Project under this Article 18.3. 18.4 The enumeration of the foregoing remedies shall not be deemed to be a waiver of any other remedies at law or in equity to which the Non Delinquent Party or the Non Defaulting Party is legally entitled. ARTICLE 19 Term and Termination 19.1 This Agreement shall become effective as of the date first above written, and shall continue in full force and effect as long as the Project is interconnected to AP's Transmission System, unless modified by written agreement of the Parties (such period, the "Term"). 19.3 The applicable provisions of this Agreement shall continue in effect after cancellation or termination hereof to the extent necessary to provide for final billings, billing adjustments and payments pertaining to liability and indemnification obligations arising from acts or events that occurred while this Agreement was in effect. 19.4This Agreement can be terminated by either Party with written notice pursuant to Article 24 a)Pursuant to Article 18, or b)Pursuant to Article 2.1, or d) Termination is mutually agreed upon by both Parties. 19.5 After termination of this Agreement, neither Party shall have any obligation under this Agreement to continue the interconnection of their respective facilities. Any subsequent reconnection of the Project to Transmission System shall be governed by the laws and regulations governing electric utility interconnection at that time.
