record_data.filing_title: Allegheny Power Open Access Transmission Tariff Baseline Filing

record_data.record_narrative_name: Methodology To Assess Available Transmission Capability
record_data.record_plain_text: ATTACHMENT C Methodology To Assess Available Transmission Capability The Transmission Provider will assess the capability of the Transmission System to provide Network Integration or Point-to-Point Transmission Service pursuant to this Tariff. Consideration of a Transmission Service request requires a system assessment by the Transmission Provider. The assessment encompasses several stages. The first is a data gathering stage. Data gathering begins with the creation of a system model that will include: (1) loads and projected loads of the Transmission Provider s Native Load Customers, captive Wholesale Customers, and Network Integration Customers; (2) Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service Customers under this Tariff and Firm Transmission Service from the Transmission Provider pursuant to other tariffs, rate schedules, and contracts; (3) Transmission Service to be provided in response to previously pending applications for Network Integration and Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service under this Tariff; (4) configuration changes of the Transmission System for planned, unplanned or forced equipment outages; (5) the availability of generating units to make up for planned, unplanned or forced outages; and (6) other Transmission System modeling assumptions not covered in (1) through (5) in accordance with Good Utility Practice. Once the model is complete a determination of the proposed use of the Transmission System is made. If the results of the assessment indicate that an internal transmission facility(s) and/or a transmission interface facility(s) reaches a reliability limit, the need for facility enhancement(s), replacement(s), or addition(s) may be necessary in order to accommodate the request for Network Integration or Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service. A reliability limit may be in the form of a thermal, voltage, and/or stability limit. The determination includes an evaluation of system performance and a calculation of Total Transfer Capability (TTC) and Available Transfer Capability (ATC). Included in this calculation, so that no Network Integration or Point-to-Point Transmission Service request loads a transmission facility in excess of its respective reliability limit or violates operating practices and procedures, are criteria established by the North American Electric Reliability Council (NERC), the applicable regional reliability council, and/or the Transmission Provider. NERC has established concepts for calculating ATC and TTC. In addition to NERC, the applicable regional reliability council and/or the Transmission Provider establish regional and company operating and planning guidelines. The Transmission Provider will, in accordance with Good Utility Practice, calculate the ATC and TTC. ATC and TTC may be further delineated into firm (non-recallable) and non-firm (recallable) sub-components to adequately address the interrelation and complementary effects of those types of services on the administration of ATC and TTC. Reliability limits in the form of equipment thermal ratings are provided by the manufacturer. Additional facility rating criteria may be established by applicable regional reliability councils. The Transmission Provider will also determine if the proposed use of the Transmission System will result in unacceptable system voltages. Acceptable and unacceptable steady-state voltages are defined by criteria established by NERC, the applicable regional reliability councils, and the Transmission Provider in accordance with Good Utility Practice. It should be noted that the TTC and ATC values are calculated in accordance with definitions and applications established in the June 1996, NERC Available Transfer Capability Definitions and Determinations document. In addition, all non-recallable values are established by removing all recallable and counter flowing non-recallable transactions from the power flow model. All recallable ATC values are determined by referencing the line flows as established for the study period (i.e. next day, next week, etc.) and calculating in incremental value over and above what has already been represented in the power flow model. This means that counter acting non-recallable and recallable transactions are in place when establishing all recallable ATC values for a given transmission path. By doing this, any ATC calculation made is incremental from that point and dependent on those transactions being in place when establishing the new recallable ATC value(s). When making this assumption, it should be recognized that there may be times when certain transmission paths have a recallable ATC that is calculated to be higher than the path s TTC. In accordance, with Good Utility Practice and to recognize the commonality of concurrent network use by multiple systems, it is common to limit the transfer capability of any one system within an interconnection to either a pre-defined reasonable maximum transfer level or the intuitive maximum power flow level at which the transfer tests are being made. Therefore, in addition to the method selected for handling known transactions which is described in the paragraph above, it should also be recognized that all of the TTC and ATC values are screened for compliance with these reasonability limits so as not to overstate the capability of the transmission system. For reliability purposes, AP has elected to limit some of its transmission paths at a pre-defined transfer level. For example, transactions going east across the AP network are subject to a 5000 MW cutoff, while similar transactions oriented to the west are also subject to a 5000 MW limit. This means that for any test made of west to east transactions, (e.g., AP to PJM, AEP to PJM, etc.) 5000 MW is the maximum TTC or ATC value that AP will accept for posting at this time. Conversely, for any test made of east to west transactions (e.g. AP to AEP, PJM to AEP, etc.), 5000 MW is the maximum TTC and/or ATC that AP will accept for positing at this time. All of the studies to evaluate, measure and determine the effect of the Transmission Service request require some type of action. These actions range from doing nothing to constructing new facilities. When new facilities are required to accommodate the Transmission Service request, planning studies are necessary to determine the method to enhance, replace or add new facilities. The design criteria or planning criteria used by most Transmission Providers require that a failure of any one piece of equipment (i.e. single contingency) will not result in the remaining facilities experiencing unacceptable voltages (high or low) or excessive loading (i.e. above the normal rating). These criteria must be satisfied at various load levels as selected for the analysis by the Transmission Provider and the associated Transmission Service request in accordance with Good Utility Practice. There may be exceptions to the single contingency criterion. For example, where radial transmission or distribution circuits supply a single substation (e.g. owned by an individual customers), or a substation grouping may be tapped off a single feeder, or a substation grouping has dual supply sharing a common right-of-way, more than one piece of equipment could be involved in the outage. It should also be recognized that the Transmission provider must be able to maintain, rehabilitate and when required construct new facilities. For that reason contingencies beyond the first contingency will also be tested on a case by case limited basis. Breaker duty on transmission circuit breakers will also be evaluated in the form of a short circuit analysis. These studies will evaluate breaker duty on the circuit breakers to ensure the facility additions or enhancements do not result in over stressed circuit breakers. Over stressed circuit breakers would result in unreliable operation of the breaker and decrease system reliability. In addition to the steady-state performance criteria described above, the Transmission Provider is also responsible for and required to take into account the dynamic stability performance of the system to ensure that any credibly possible disturbance does not result in cascading tripping of transmission facilities. The criteria applied are those provided by NERC and the applicable regional reliability council. The Transmission Provider will rely upon the information supplied in applications by Customers to assess the ATC and TTC of the Transmission System.

record_data.record_plain_text: SCHEDULE 13 TABLE OF CONTENTS I. Definitions----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1 Competitive Service Provider (CSP)---------------------------------- 2 Designated Agent--------------------------------------------------------- 3 Marginal Hourly Price-------------------------------------------------- II. Terms and Conditions-------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers------ 7.1 Billing Procedure-------------------------------------------------------- 7.3 Customer Default-------------------------------------------------------- Section 11 Creditworthiness--------------------------------------------------------------- Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service------------------------------ Section 28.4 Secondary Service----------------------------------------------------------- Section 28.5 Real Power Losses------------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service-------------------------------- Section 29.2 Application Procedures-------------------------------------------------------- Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities-------------------------------------------------- Section 34 Rates and Charges-------------------------------------------------------------- i Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service------------------------------------------------------------------------- ii Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service--------------------- iii Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service------------------------------------------------------------------------- iv Regulation and Frequency Response Service---------------------------- v Charges for Energy Imbalance Service----------------------------------- Supply Energy Imbalance--------------------------------------------------- Consumption Energy Imbalance------------------------------------------- vi Charges for Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service--------- vii Charges for Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service---- Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee--------------------------------------------- Schedule 1 Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service----------------------- Schedule 2 Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service--------------------------------------------------------------------------- Schedule 3 Regulation and Frequency Response Service----------------------------- Schedule 4 Energy Imbalance Service---------------------------------------------------- Supply Energy Imbalance---------------------------------------------------- Consumption Energy Imbalance--------------------------------------------- Schedule 5 Operating Reserve Spinning Reserve Service------------------------- Schedule 6 Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service------------------- Schedule 9 Real Power Transmission Loss Service------------------------------------ Network Operating Agreement-------------------------------------------------------------- Section 4.4 Scheduling of Network Integration Transmission Service------------ Section 5.0 Default------------------------------------------------------------------------- Attachment H Annual Transmission Revenue Requirement for Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service--------------------------------------------------------------------- RETAIL TRANSMISSION SERVICE - VIRGINIA Retail transmission services pursuant to the Commission s Order Nos. 888, 888-A and B, 889 and 889-A and B shall be made available under this Schedule 13 to unbundled retail customers in the state of Virginia with the right to choose their electric suppliers. Service shall be provided according to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Tariff which is hereby incorporated herein except as modified below. I.Definitions 1.Competitive Service Provider (CSP) shall mean a person or corporation, (including municipal corporations which choose to provide service outside their municipal limits as prescribed by state law), broker or marketer, aggregator, scheduling coordinator, or any other entity selling to end-use customers (including a local distribution company providing default service) electricity or related services utilizing the jurisdictional transmission and distribution facilities of a local distribution company. 2.Designated Agent shall mean any entity that performs actions or functions on behalf of the Transmission Provider, an Eligible Customer, or the Transmission Customer required under the Tariff. 3.Marginal Hourly Price shall mean the price at which Consumption Energy Imbalance will be traded. The price is the Transmission Provider s out-of-pocket cost for energy purchased during the hour in which the Consumption Energy Imbalance occurs. Terms and Conditions Retail Transmission Services shall be provided pursuant to the AP Pro Forma Open Access Transmission Service Tariff, as amended ( OATT ) except as modified below. The CSP(s) shall act as a Designated Agent for an Eligible Customer(s), unless otherwise indicated below. Section 2.2 Reservation Priority for Existing Firm Service Customers. Eligible Customers classified as retail customers taking unbundled transmission service pursuant to a state requirement that the Transmission Provider offer the transmission service, or pursuant to a voluntary offer of such service by the Transmission Provider with a contract term of one-year or more have the right to continue to take transmission service from the Transmission Provider when the contract expires, rolls over or is renewed. This transmission reservation priority is independent of whether the existing customer continues to purchase capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider or elects to purchase capacity and energy from another CSP. If at the end of the contract term the Transmission Provider s Transmission System cannot accommodate all of the requests for transmission service, the existing firm service customer must agree to accept a contract term at least equal to a competing request by any new Eligible Customer and to pay the current just and reasonable rate, as approved by the Commission, for such service. This transmission reservation priority for existing retail firm service customers is an ongoing right that may be exercised at the end of all firm contract terms of one-year or longer. Section 7.1 Billing Procedure Within a reasonable time after the first day of each month, the Transmission Provider shall submit an invoice to the CSP for charges for all Network Integrated Transmission Service and Ancillary Services furnished under the Tariff during the preceding month. Charges for Network Integrated Transmission Service, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control, Regulation and Frequency Response, Operative Reserve Spinning and Operating Reserve Supplemental services shall be based on meter data collected from Eligible Customer(s) within the calendar month. The Transmission Provider shall also charge the CSP for any Supply Energy Imbalance service rendered to the CSP during the calendar month and for an estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance as related to the calendar month. Approximately 60 days later, the CSP shall also be billed an adjustment for Consumption Energy Imbalance after all Eligible Customer(s) energy usage occurring during the calendar month is collected from meter readings and processed. This adjustment will be determined as the difference between such estimated Consumption Energy Imbalance and the Consumption Energy Imbalance determined after meter data collection. The invoices shall be paid by the CSP within twenty (20) days of receipt. All payments shall be made in immediately available funds payable to the Transmission Provider, or by wire transfer to a bank named by the Transmission Provider. Section 7.3 Customer Default In the event the CSP fails for any reason other than a billing dispute as described below, to make payment to the Transmission Provider on or before the due date as described above, and such failure of payment is not corrected within thirty (30) calendar days after the Transmission Provider notifies the CSP to cure such failure, a default by the CSP shall be deemed to exist. Upon the occurrence of a default, the Transmission Provider may initiate a proceeding with the Commission to terminate service but shall not terminate service until the Commission so approves any such request; provided however, that in the event that a state required retail access program provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another CSP, then the Transmission Provider may, upon default by an CSP, immediately terminate service to the defaulting CSP for the load of such end-use customers. In the event of a billing dispute between the Transmission Provider and the CSP, the Transmission Provider will continue to provide service under the Service Agreement as long as the CSP (i) continues to make all payments not in dispute, and (ii) pays into an independent escrow account the portion of the invoice in dispute, pending resolution of such dispute. If the CSP fails to meet these two requirements for continuation of service, then the Transmission Provider may provide notice to the CSP of its intention to suspend service in sixty (60) days, in accordance with Commission policy, or in the case of a state required retail access program that provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another CSP, immediately terminate transmission service to the defaulting CSP as provided above. Section 11 Creditworthiness For the purpose of determining the ability of the Transmission Customer or CSP to meet its obligations related to service hereunder, the Transmission Provider may require reasonable credit review procedures. The Transmission Customer or CSP will be considered creditworthy if (1) the Transmission Customer s or CSP s long-term unsecured debt securities are, and remain, rated a minimum of BBB or Baa2 by Standard & Poor s or Moody s, respectively, (b) the Transmission Customer or CSP either prepays for service or provides an irrevocable standby letter of credit issued by a domestic or Canadian bank with a minimum A (Standard & Poor s or Dominion) or A2 (Moody s) long-term unsecured debt rating, for an amount equal to the sum of the charges pursuant to this Tariff for the shorter of (i) the three (3) individual months when such charges would be greatest, or (ii) the term of the Service Agreement based on mutually agreeable load factors pursuant to this Tariff, (c) the Transmission Customer or CSP has, as determined by Allegheny Power in its sole discretion, a qualified long-term payment history with Allegheny Power, or (d) the Transmission Customer s or CSP s parent company, in a form satisfactory to Allegheny Power, guarantees responsibility for all financial obligations associated with the Service Agreement and such parent company conforms to the minimum ratings specified above. Section 28.3 Network Integration Transmission Service The Transmission Provider will provide firm transmission service over its Transmission System to the CSP on behalf of its Eligible Customers for the delivery of capacity and energy from its designated Network Resources to service its Network Loads on a basis that is comparable to the Transmission Provider s use of the Transmission System to reliably serve its Native Load Customers. The CSP must designate its Network Resources via NERC Tag by 1:00 p.m., one (1) business day before the delivery of power. Firm Available Transmission Capability will be awarded on a first-come, first-serve basis based on the receipt time of the NERC Tag. Section 28.4 Secondary Service The CSP on behalf of its Eligible Customers may use the Transmission Provider s Transmission System to deliver energy to its Network Loads from resources that have not been designated as Network Resources. The CSP shall request to change generation sources to non-Network Resources via NERC Tag. Such energy shall be transmitted, on an as-available-basis, at no additional charge. Deliveries from resources other than Network Resources will have a higher priority than any Non-Firm Point-to-Point Transmission Service under Part II of the Tariff. Section 28.5 Real Power Losses Real Power Losses are associated with all transmission service. The CSP is responsible for supplying losses associated with its Eligible Customer(s). The applicable Real Power Loss factors are as listed below in Schedule 9 of this Schedule 13. Section 29.1 Condition Precedent for Receiving Service Subject to the terms and conditions of Part III of the Tariff, the Transmission Provider will provide Network Integration Transmission Service to any Eligible Customer, provided that (i) the Eligible Customer completes an Application for service as provided under Part III of the Tariff, as required (ii) the Eligible Customer and the Transmission Provider complete the technical arrangements set forth in Sections 29.3 and 29.4, (iii) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Service Agreement with the Commission, and (iv) the Transmission Provider files an unexecuted Network Operating Agreement with the Commission pursuant to Attachment G. The Eligible Customer and CSP shall be bound by the Terms and Conditions of the OATT including this Schedule 13. Section 29.2 Application Procedures An Eligible Customer (or a Designated Agent) requesting service under Part III of the Tariff may be required to submit an Application, with a deposit approximating the charge for one month of service, to the Transmission Provider as far as possible in advance of the month in which service is to commence. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Transmission Provider may, on a non-discriminatory basis, waive the requirement that a deposit accompany an Application where the Eligible Customer has established its creditworthiness pursuant to Section 11 of this Tariff and is not in default in its obligation under this Section 7.3 of this Tariff at the time of Application. The Transmission Provider will bill the Eligible Customer for any reasonable costs incurred by the Transmission Provider in connection with its review of the Application. Such bill will contain a complete accounting of all costs included. Unless subject to the procedures in Section 2, Completed Applications for Network Integration Transmission Service will be assigned a priority according to the date and time the Application is received, with the earliest Application receiving the highest priority. Applications should be submitted by entering the information listed below on the Transmission Provider s OASIS. Prior to implementation of the Transmission Provider s OASIS, a Completed Application may be submitted by (i) transmitting the required information to the Transmission Provider by telefax, or (ii) providing the information by telephone over the Transmission Provider s time recorded telephone line. Each of these methods will provide a time-stamped record for establishing the service priority of the Application. A Completed Application shall provide all of the information included in 18 CFR 2.20 including but not limited to the following: (i)The identity, address, telephone number and facsimile number of the party requesting service; (ii) A statement that the party requesting service is, or will be upon commencement of service, an Eligible Customer under the Tariff; (i)A description of the Network Load at each delivery point. This description should separately identify and provide the Eligible Customer s best estimate of the total loads to be served at each transmission voltage level, and the load to be served from each Transmission Provider substation at the same transmission voltage level. The description should include a ten (10) year forecast of summer and winter load and resource requirements beginning with the first year after the service is scheduled to commence; (ii)The amount and location of any interruptible loads included in the Network Load. This shall include the summer and winter capacity requirements for each interruptible load (had such load not been interruptible), that portion of the load subject to interruption, the conditions under which an interruption can be implemented and any limitations on the amount and frequency of interruptions. An Eligible Customer should identify the amount of interruptible customer load (if any) included in the 10 year load forecast provided in response to (iii) above; (iii)A description of Network Resources (current and 10-year projection), which shall include, for each Network Resource: Unit size and amount of capacity from that unit to be designated as Network Resource VAR capability (both leading and lagging) of all generators Operating restrictions Any periods of restricted operations throughout the year Maintenance schedules Minimum loading level of unit Normal operating level of unit Any must-run unit designations required for system reliability or contract reasons Approximate variable generating cost ($MWH) for redispatch computations Arrangement governing sale and delivery of power to third parties from generating facilities located in the Transmission Provider Control Area, where only a portion of unit output is designated as a Network Resource Description of purchased power designated as a Network Resource including source of supply, Control Area location, transmission arrangements and delivery point(s) to the Transmission Provider s Transmission System; (iv)Description of Eligible Customer s transmission system: Load flow and stability data, such as real and reactive parts of the load, lines, transformers, reactive devices and load type, including normal and emergency ratings of all transmission equipment in a load flow format compatible with that used by the Transmission Provider Operating restrictions needed for reliability Operating guides employed by system operators Contractual restrictions or committed uses of the Eligible Customers transmission system, other than the Eligible Customer s Network Loads and Resources Location of Network Resources described in subsection (v) above 10 year projection of system expansions or upgrades Transmission System maps that include any proposed expansions or upgrades Thermal ratings of Eligible Customer s Control Area ties with other Control Areas; and (v)Service Commencement Date and the term of the requested Network Integration Transmission Service. The minimum term for Network Integration Transmission Service is one year. Unless the Parties agree to a different time frame, the Transmission Provider must acknowledge the request within ten (10) days of receipt. The acknowledgement must include a date by which a response, including a Service Agreement, will be sent to the Eligible Customer. If an Application fails to meet the requirements of this section, the Transmission Provider shall notify the Eligible Customer requesting service within fifteen (15) days of receipt and specify the reasons for such failure. Wherever possible, the Transmission Provider will attempt to remedy deficiencies in the Application through informal communications with the Eligible Customer. If such efforts are unsuccessful, the Transmission Provider shall return the Application without prejudice to the Eligible Customer filing a new or revised Application that fully complies with the requirements of this section. The Eligible Customer will be assigned a new priority consistent with the date of the new or revised Application. The Transmission Provider shall treat this information consistent with the standards of conduct contained in Part 37 of the Commission's regulations. Section 29.4 Eligible Customer Facilities The provision of Network Integration Transmission Service shall be conditioned upon the Eligible Customer's constructing, maintaining and operating the facilities on its side of each delivery point or interconnection necessary to reliably deliver capacity and energy from the Transmission Provider's transmission system to the Eligible Customer or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. The Eligible Customer shall be solely responsible for constructing or installing all facilities on the Eligible Customer's side of each such delivery point or interconnection or, with respect to Retail Transmission Service provided pursuant to a state required retail access program, for otherwise arranging for the delivery of its energy from the delivery point or interconnection. Section 34 Rates and Charges Charges shall be in accordance with OATT rates and charges except as listed below. The CSP is responsible for paying all OATT charges on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). (i) Network Integration Transmission Service for Retail Transmission Service Charges for Network Integration Transmission Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) Retail Transmission Service charge. Network Integration Transmission Service charges are as listed in Attachment H of this Schedule 13. (i)Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service There is no charge for this service. (iii) Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service Charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service. Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service charges are as listed in Schedule 2 of this Schedule 13. (iv) Regulation and Frequency Response Service Charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service. Regulation and Frequency Response Service charges are as listed in Schedule 3 of this Schedule 13. (v)Charges for Energy Imbalance Service Supply Energy Imbalance Charges for Supply Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between a Pre-schedule and associated Schedule(s). Supply Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 13. Consumption Energy Imbalance Charges for Consumption Energy Imbalance arises when there is a difference between the Pre-Schedule and the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption. Consumption Energy Imbalance charges are as listed in Schedule 4 of this Schedule 13. (vi) Charges for Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service Charges for Spinning Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service. Operating Reserve Spinning Reserve Service charges are as listed in Schedule 5 of this Schedule 13. (vii) Charges for Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service. Operating Reserve Supplemental Reserve Service charges are as listed in Schedule 6 of this Schedule 13. Section 35.3 Network Operating Committee A Network Operating Committee (Committee) may be established to coordinate operating criteria for the Parties' respective responsibilities for Eligible Customer(s) under the Network Operating Agreement. Each CSP serving Eligible Customer(s) within the Transmission Provider's Control Area shall be entitled to have at least one representative on the Committee. The Committee shall meet from time to time as need requires. Schedule 1, Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service1 This service is required to schedule the movement of power through, out of, within, or into a Control Area. This service can be provided only by the operator of the Control Area in which the transmission facilities used for transmission service are located. Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator) or indirectly by the Transmission Provider making arrangements with the Control Area operator that performs this service for the Transmission Provider's Transmission System. The CSP must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider or the Control Area operator. The charges for Scheduling, System Control and Dispatch Service are to be based on the rates set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. There is no charge for this service. Schedule 2, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service2 In order to maintain transmission voltages on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities within acceptable limits, generation facilities under the control of the Control Area operator are operated to produce (or absorb) reactive power. Thus, Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service must be provided for each transaction on the Transmission Provider's transmission facilities. The amount of Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service that must be supplied with respect to the CSP's transaction will be determined based on the reactive power support necessary to maintain transmission voltages within limits that are generally accepted in the region and consistently adhered to by the Transmission Provider. Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service is to be provided directly by the Transmission Provider (if the Transmission Provider is the Control Area operator) or indirectly by the Transmission Provider making arrangements with the Control Area operator that performs this service for the Transmission Provider's Transmission System. The CSP must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s) from the Transmission Provider or the Control Area operator. The charges for such service will be based on the rates set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by the Control Area operator. Charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Reactive Supply and Voltage Control from Generation Sources Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $0.00017/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $0.00014/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $0.00014/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $0.06/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $0.07/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL and SL (street and area lighting): $0.00004/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $0.038/kW Schedule 3, Regulation and Frequency Response Service3 Regulation and Frequency Response Service is necessary to provide for the continuous balancing of resources (generation and interchange) with load and for maintaining scheduled Interconnection frequency at sixty cycles per second (60 Hz). Regulation and Frequency Response Service is accomplished by committing on-line generation whose output is raised or lowered (predominantly through the use of automatic generating control equipment) as necessary to follow the moment-by-moment changes in load. The obligation to maintain this balance between resources and load lies with the Transmission Provider (or the Control Area operator that performs this function for the Transmission Provider). The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The CSP must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Regulation and Frequency Response Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $0.00018/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $0.00016/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $0.00016/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $0.06/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $0.07/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL and SL (street and area lighting): $0.00004/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $0.038/kW Schedule 4, Energy Imbalance Service4 Energy Imbalance Service is provided when a difference occurs between the scheduled and the actual delivery of energy to a load located within a Control Area over a single hour. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The CSP must purchase this service from the Transmission Provider on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Energy Imbalance Service will be provided if: 1.An imbalance exists between a Pre-Schedule(s) and associated Schedule(s), i.e., Supply Energy Imbalance. 2. An imbalance exists between a Pre-Schedule(s) and the actual metered consumption, i.e., Consumption Energy Imbalance. Supply Energy Imbalance Supply Energy Imbalance arises when there is the difference between a Pre-Schedule and associated Schedule(s). A Pre-Schedule is defined as an aggregate hourly projection of load or capacity, compiled by the Transmission Provider in a manner that is consistent with Control Area protocols, used to forecast generation and transmission transfer capability required to meet load for customers within the Transmission Provider's Control Area. One aggregate Pre-Schedule is compiled for each CSP one business day before the delivery of power. A Schedule, based upon a Pre-Schedule, is prepared by a CSP for receipt and delivery of capacity and energy for the benefit of customers; the CSP submits the schedule to the Transmission Provider's Control Area in the format prescribed by the Transmission Provider. The Schedule or combination of Schedules is intended to meet the CSP's Pre-Schedule. Discrepancies between a Pre-Schedule and associated Schedule(s) will occur if CSP fails to meet its Pre-Schedule, in whole or in part. CSP remains solely responsible for supplying a Schedule(s) and for notifying the Transmission Provider if it will not deliver power to meet its Pre-Schedule. CSP' failure to supply a Schedule(s) or to deliver power to meet the Pre-Schedule will require the Transmission Provider's Control Area operator to automatically supply the deficient amount of power. Charges for Supply Energy Imbalance shall be equal to the greater of: (i) $0.10/KWh of such energy supply, or (ii) 110% of the out-of-pocket cost of supplying this energy. Consumption Energy Imbalance Consumption Energy Imbalance is the difference between the Pre-Schedule and the Customer's actual metered consumption. When such a difference arises, the Transmission Provider's Control Area will react accordingly. Specifically, if consumption is greater than the Pre-Schedule, the Transmission Provider will automatically supply power to make up for the deficiency. If consumption is less than the Pre-Schedule, the Transmission Provider will automatically back down contracted generation by the amount of oversupply. Consumption Energy Imbalance will be traded as follows: (i)If CSP s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption is greater than the Pre-Schedule, CSP will pay the Company the Marginal Hourly Price. (ii) If CSP s Eligible Customer(s) metered consumption is less than the Pre-Schedule, the Company will pay the CSP the Marginal Hourly Price. Schedule 5, Operating Reserve - Spinning Reserve Service5 Spinning Reserve Service is needed to serve load immediately in the event of a system contingency. Spinning Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line and loaded at less than maximum output. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The CSP must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Spinning Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Spinning Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Spinning Reserve Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $0.00025/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $0.00021/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $0.00021/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $0.09/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $0.10/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL and SL (street and area lighting): $0.00007/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $0.057/kW Schedule 6, Operating Reserve - Supplemental Reserve Service6 Supplemental Reserve Service is needed to serve load in the event of a system contingency; however, it is not available immediately to serve load but rather within a short period of time. Supplemental Reserve Service may be provided by generating units that are on-line but unloaded, by quick-start generation or by interruptible load. The Transmission Provider must offer this service when the transmission service is used to serve load within its Control Area. The CSP must purchase this service on behalf of its Eligible Customer(s). The amount of and charges for Supplemental Reserve Service are set forth below. To the extent the Control Area operator performs this service for the Transmission Provider, charges to the CSP are to reflect only a pass-through of the costs charged to the Transmission Provider by that Control Area operator. Charges for Supplemental Reserve Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Supplemental Reserve Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing month by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): $0.00025/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): $0.00021/kWh Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): $0.00021/kWh Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): $0.09/kW Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): $0.10/kW Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL and SL (street and area lighting): $0.00007/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): $0.057/kW Schedule 9, Real Power Transmission Loss Service7 Real Power Transmission Loss Service is needed to serve the real power lost when a CSP transmits power through, from, within, and into the Control Area. The CSP is responsible for securing and delivering Real Power Transmission Losses. For convenience, combined transmission and distribution loss amounts that will be applied when a customer takes service from facilities at voltages below those of the transmission system are as set forth below. These voltages are stated in ranges that are consistent with The Potomac Edison Company s retail rate schedules in Virginia. The combined transmission and distribution line losses for Secondary, Primary, Subtransmission, and Transmission voltage levels shall be calculated by multiplying hourly kWh sales delivered to customer(s) served at these voltage levels by the applicable line loss factor. Line loss factors are time-differentiated as on-peak and off-peak for each voltage classification. The on-peak line loss factors apply to the hours ended 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. The off-peak line loss factors apply to all remaining hours. The applicable on-peak and off-peak line loss factors are: Voltage served On peak line losses Off peak line losses Secondary (<1kv) 9.524% 8.686% Primary Load (1kv to l5kv) 7.551 6.904 Primary Source (1kv to 15kv) 3.634 3.331 Subtransmission (15kv to 100kv) 3.746 3.464 Transmission (>100kv) 2.245 2.028 The Transmission Provider will make available the mapping of the voltage line loss factors to the respective rate schedules (rate codes) on the Company website. NETWORK OPERATING AGREEMENT Section 4.4 Scheduling of Network Integration Transmission Service All scheduling practices and schedules submitted by the CSP will comply with applicable North American Electric Reliability Council (or its successor organization) criteria. CSP shall submit all schedules electronically via NERC Tag. As used herein, an Energy Schedule for Reservations of Network Integrated Transmission Service (scheduled daily), shall refer to the Eligible Customer(s) Schedule provided by Customers' CSP for the receipt and delivery of energy with the Transmission Provider. The Energy Schedule may be communicated in whole megawatts to the Transmission Provider via an electronic or dynamic schedule. Electronic Schedules Energy Schedules for Eligible Customer(s) Network Integration Transmission Service must be submitted via NERC Tag by the CSP to the Transmission Provider no later than 1:00 p.m., one (1) business day before the delivery of power. A business day is a weekday excepting Company holidays. Scheduling changes, submitted via NERC Tag, to accommodate changes in generation sources will be permitted up to twenty (20) minutes, before the start of the next clock hour or the next half hour provided that the Delivering Party and Receiving Party are all in agreement with the schedule modification. The Transmission Provider will furnish to the Delivering Party's system operator, hour-to-hour schedules equal to those furnished by the Receiving Party (unless reduced for losses) and shall deliver the capacity and energy provided by such schedules. Should the CSP, Delivering Party or Receiving Party revise or terminate any Energy Schedule, such party shall immediately notify the Transmission Provider, and the Transmission Provider shall have the right to adjust accordingly the Energy Schedule for capacity and energy to be received and to be delivered. Schedule changes to accommodate 30 minute interruptible loads will also be permitted. Such schedule changes shall be provided by the CSP to the Transmission Provider as soon as possible after Eligible Customer or CSP has been notified of the requirement to drop the interruptible load, but in no event later than 20 minutes before the start of the interruption. The CSP shall specifically tell the Transmission Provider when schedule changes are attributable to 30-minute interruptible loads. In such instances, CSP will not be penalized for Supply Energy Imbalance arising from schedule changes due to interruptible loads. However, failure of a customer to drop the interruptible portion of its load will be reflected in the Consumption Energy Imbalance billed to the CSP. Section 5.0 Default If the Eligible Customer or CSP fails to perform consistent with the terms and conditions of this agreement, then the Eligible Customer or CSP will be deemed to be in default and service may be suspended immediately, subject to a filing of a notice of termination with the FERC, provided however, in the event the Transmission Customer or CSP fails, for any reason other than a billing dispute as described below, to make payment to the Transmission Provider on or before the due date as described above, and such failure of payment is not corrected within thirty (30) calendar days after the Transmission Provider notifies the Eligible Customer or CSP to cure such failure, a default by the Eligible Customer of CSP shall be deemed to exist. Upon the occurrence of a default, the Transmission Provider may initiate a proceeding with the Commission to terminate service but shall not terminate service until the Commission so approves any such request; provided however, that in the event that a state required retail access program provides for continuation of retail service to affected end-use customers by another CSP, then the Transmission Provider may, upon default by an CSP immediately terminate service to the defaulting CSP for the load of such end-use customers. ATTACHMENT H Annual Transmission Revenue Requirement For Network Integration Transmission Service For Retail Transmission Service8 Charges for Network Integration Transmission Service shall be determined by aggregating the CSP s Eligible Customer(s) Retail Transmission Service charges. The Eligible Customer(s) charges for Network Integration Transmission Service is determined by multiplying the Eligible Customer(s) billed kW or billed kWh for the billing months by the following applicable rates: Rate Schedule R (residential): All kWh $0.00278/kWh Rate Schedule C (commercial/industrial): Minimum kW $0.11/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-700) $0.00282/kWh 2nd Block (over 700) $0.00197/kWh When Customer requires capacity over 7.5 kilowatts, the first energy block shall be increased 53 kilowatt-hours for each one-half kilowatt of capacity required in excess of 7.5 kilowatts. The second energy block shall then include all kilowatt-hours in excess of the first energy block as adjusted. Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a 30-minute interval during a billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedule G (commercial/industrial): Minimum kW $0.11/kW Demand Rate (kW) 1st Block (0-7.5) $0.00/kW 2nd Block (over 7.5) $0.09/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-700) $0.00282/kWh 2nd Block (over 700) $0.00197/kWh Capacity required is the highest metered demand in kilowatts established over a thirty (30) minute interval during the billing period. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be the capacity required in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) the highest kilowatt capacity required in the previous eleven months. For connections without a demand meter, the kilowatt capacity required shall be defined as the number of kilowatt-hours used in the current month, but not less than one-half (1/2) of the highest kilowatt-hours used in any of the previous twelve months, divided by 250. Rate Schedule PH (commercial/industrial): Demand Rate (kW) Minimum kW $0.21/kW All other kW $0.37/kW Energy Rate (kWh) 1st Block (0-100,000) $0.00140/kWh 2nd Block (over 100,000) $0.00128/kWh Kilowatt billing capacity during a billing period shall be the highest of the following, but not less than 50 kilowatts: 1. The maximum 30-minute metered kilowatt capacity, or 2. 50% of the maximum instantaneous kilowatt capacity, or 3. For Customers whose contracted billing capacity is 200 kW or greater, and who contract for "off-peak" service, the billing capacity for any month shall be the maximum capacity measured during "on-peak" hours plus 25 percent of the amount that the maximum capacity measured during "off-peak" hours exceeds the maximum "on-peak" capacity. "Off-Peak" hours shall be from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. daily plus all hours of Sunday. Capacity to be used in determining the minimum charge shall be one-half (1/2) of the highest kilowatt capacity required in the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedule PP (commercial/industrial): Demand Rate (kW) All kW $0.39/kW Energy Rate (kWh) All kWh $0.00121/kWh Kilowatt billing capacity during a billing period shall be the highest of: 1. The maximum 30-minute metered kilowatt capacity, or 2. For Customers contracting for "off-peak" service, the billing capacity for any month shall be the maximum capacity measured during "on-peak" hours plus 25 percent of the amount that the maximum capacity measured during "off-peak" hours exceeds the maximum "on-peak" capacity. "Off-Peak" hours shall be from 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. daily plus all hours of Sunday. 3. 60% of the maximum instantaneous kilowatt capacity. However, the "Billing Capacity" for any month shall not be less than the highest of: (a) 5,000 kilowatts, or, (b) 75% of the kilowatt capacity specified in the Electric Service Agreement, or, (c) 75% of the highest "Billing Capacity" established during the preceding eleven months. Rate Schedules OL, AL, MSL and SL (street and area lighting): All kWh $0.00063/kWh Rate Schedule AGS (commercial/industrial): Firm Standby Power 1st Block (0-100 kW) $0.265/kW 2nd Block (over 100 kW) $0.247/kW Interruptible Standby Power 1st Block (0-100 kW) $0.253/kW 2nd Block (over 100 kW) $0.235/kW Maintenance Power All kW $0.235/kW Energy Rate (kWh) All kWh $0.00076/kWh The retail transmission rates for purposes of the Network Integration Transmission Service (stated above) are shown in The Potomac Edison Company s Virginia rate tariffs and are based upon OATT rates on file with the Commission. These rates are based on an annual transmission revenue requirement (without Ancillary Services) for The Potomac Edison Company s Retail Customers of $5,594,042. The amount listed above shall be effective until amended by the Transmission Provider or modified by the Commission. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties intending to be legally bound, have caused this Schedule 13-Retail Transmission Service to be executed by their authorized officials. Competitive Service Provider Transmission Provider Company____________________ Allegheny Power By_________________________ By_________________________ Name_______________________ Name_______________________ Title________________________ Title________________________ Date________________________ Date_______________________

Service under this agreement shall terminate on such date as mutually agreed upon by the parties. 5.0 The Transmission Provider agrees to provide and the Transmission Customer agrees to take and pay for Firm Point-To-Point Transmission Service in accordance with the provisions of Part II of the Tariff and this Service Agreement. 6.0 Any notice or request made to or by either Party regarding this Service Agreement shall be made to the representative of the other Party as indicated below. Service under this agreement shall terminate on _____________________. Upon termination, Customer remains responsible for any outstanding charges including all costs incurred and apportioned or assigned to Customer according to Commission policy. 4.0 The Transmission Provider agrees to provide and the Transmission Customer agrees to take and pay for Network Integration Transmission Service in accordance with the provisions of Parts I and III of the Tariff and this Service Agreement with attached Specifications. 5.0 Any notice or request made to or by either Party regarding this Service Agreement shall be made to the representative of the other Party as indicated below. Transmission Provider: Transmission Customer: ______________________________ ____________________________ ______________________________ ____________________________ ______________________________ ____________________________ ______________________________ ____________________________ 6.0The Tariff as amended from time to time is incorporated herein and made a part hereof and supersedes any other Agreement for Network Integration Service entered into by the Transmission Provider and Transmission Customer. 7.0 By signing below, Customer verifies that all information submitted to Company to provide service under the Tariff is complete, valid and accurate, and Company may rely upon such information to fulfill its responsibilities under the Tariff. IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the Parties, intending to be legally bound, have caused this Service Agreement to be executed by their respective authorized officials. If at least twelve months of load data are not available, the Load Ratio shall be determined as stated above using the averages of monthly data as available. 9.0 Compensation: Service under this Agreement may be subject to some combination of the charges detailed below. The appropriate charges for individual transactions will be determined in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Tariff. 9.1.1Transmission Charge: 9.2 System Impact and/or Facility Study Charge(s): 9.3 Direct Assignment Facilities Charge: 9.4 Ancillary Service Charges: 9.5 Charges for Dynamic or Electronic Scheduling: 10.0 Designation of party(ies) subject to reciprocal service obligation:
